content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												This, has to be the most compelling story I've ever played through in a game. One of the best, most charmingly clever, point & click titles I've ever played, a masterpiece of a game. The rustic hand drawn graphics are genuinely exquisite and really help disguise the click areas of this game. Features a really touching twisted fate mecha-folkstory, of a young robot living in a steam-punk dystopian wasteland, trying to save an enslaved princess robot. The only dialog between the characters are small animated scenes inside thought bubbles, which I think is a cool way to help tell a story without literal or verbal ques. The music is beautiful, very original and thought provoking, it really helped set the tone. You'll come across the occasional puzzle here and there and they're are some tough ones, but none are too frustrating. Unlike many titles in this genre, Machinarium consistently had me at an "aHa!" moment, great game 10/10

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												Machinarium is a point-and-click adventure game in the old fashion of "click inventory items against everything on screen until it works". You play the role of a tiny little robot dude whose first task is to rebuild his body, having been unceremoniously dumped into a junkyard. The story is told without any words, instead using the charming artstyle and clever worldbuilding to convey what's happening. It's a risky venture, especially in story-driven games like these, but Machinarium pulls it off very well; Little Robot Dude's attempts to sneak back into the city are easy to follow and very cute. Some of the puzzles can be somewhat obtuse, as is the norm for adventure games, which may put off some players, but there is a hint system built into every puzzle which lets Dude give his own insight on the solution. For times when this doesn't suffice, a short walkthrough can be unlocked with some skill at a minigame, which will give the player a storybook guide on what to do next. The wordless presentation makes Machniarum a game that can be enjoyed by all-comers of any language, age, or skill with words.Finally, the Robot Street Band's performance will stay with you forever.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												Just WOW! If you like a good adventure game with lots of things to explore, some hard puzzles and beautiful artwork, then Machinarium is your game.Without a single spoken word the story line is set very well in a world where machines have feeling too. The ambiance is amazing and the puzzles very original. You just gotta love the main character and the creative ways he finds to defeat the bad guys. The humor in the game is great too.For me this game could have lasted for several hours (days, weeks!) more, without ever boring me. The game also offers a unique hint system, so there's no need to search the internet to be able to advance in case you're stuck. I recommend not using it too often though, because the game is much more fun by solving everything yourself.If machines ever take over the world, I sure hope this is what it will look like. The downside? Maybe the fact that there's no Steam achievements. Really can't think of anything else. This game is a must-have & must-play!

number of helpful: 59 of 68 people (87%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												Machinarium is unique in so many ways, which makes it difficult to write about. It's also one of those games that is best experienced firsthand rather than after reading a spoiler-ridden review. As much as I'd like to lecture on about something that impacted me so greatly, I'm left with very little to work with; but what's there to discuss paints a picture of a masterpiece.Visually, Machinarium takes a Victorian children's book illustration style and blends it with dystopian psuedo-steampunk imagery. It's not only as striking as that description suggests but it adds layer upon layer to the gameplay and storyline. Characters and scenes are beautifully hand-drawn and painstakingly animated to bring life to the citizens of the eponymous metropolis. When I say life, I mean it metaphorically as the cast are entirely robotic; their endearing movements and actions convince you that they're genuine creatures, acting out of circuitry or as puppets.The whole game is a juxtaposition. The pure and sweet protagonist stands brightly against the grim, dank underbelly of the city whilst the dark despair of obsolescence and helplessness is often paired with love and hope. There's a great story to be discovered without ever uttering a single word, written or spoken. That alone is a remarkable feat but the characters you meet along the way are just as impressively fleshed. From the musical troupe in need of new instruments to the brutish and bullying pair that serve as antagonists; so many moments will ring in your mind when you reminisce years later, which is a powerful statement.I don't personally enjoy point and click adventures very often as I find they can sometimes be generic, predictable and require great leaps in logic. There are always exceptions, especially when it comes to LucasArts game, but lumping Machinarium into that category does little to help explain just why it's something every gamer should experience. It's on a par with the bests but ultimately nothing like them except in some key ingredients. The puzzles are frequent and never bordering on torturous like say 7th Guest, but they will certainly test you at times. It's a story-focused experience without sacrificing those times where you need to take a step back and hope for a eureka moment.There are moments where I wish you could walk across scenes a little faster, but the protagonist's gentle hobbling is endearing and easily forgiven. Puzzles that prove an irritation are quickly overshadowed by the sheer genius of the next. I'd have liked less of the retro-gaming elements but that comes down purely to preference. I can raise minor criticisms but there are no dealbreakers, nothing that will make distract from how compelling it becomes to see through Josef's quest to reunite with his girlfriend. What Machinarium does, it does extremely well.As with many games of the genre, it's a fairly brief journey, clocking in at around two hours if you're adept. It's not the longest game by any means and the ending is abrupt and slightly underwhelming but it manages not to overstay its welcome. The brevity does nothing to impact a powerful tale that had me smiling at several moments; you can put a value on the length of a game but it's much harder to put a value on something that makes you feel.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												I, a robot?Adventure is only a point-and-click away as Irreverend Opinions reviews Machinarium!---The BlurbA puzzle adventure in a stylised world of robots and amazing music.  A robot that has been abandoned by his city in pieces must pull himself together and return to not only confront some rather bad robots, but save his robot girlfriend in the process.The GoodThe first thing I noticed about Machinarium, as a first impression, is the music.  The soundtrack by Czech composer Tomáš Dvořák[floex.cz] really stands out in the task of impressing a strange new world without alienating the player from what they are engaged in.Graphically, the art style for Machinarium is quite striking, with hand-drawn animation hauntingly evocative of works by surrealist Jan Švankmajer, and seeming to be another achievement for Dvorský that fans of Amatina Design will be encouraged to see.  With their pencil-and-paper 'living comic' art style, the organic appearance of the background and characters helps to round out the artificial world with a warm and almost human sense, which helps the player to get involved with the characters quite readily.For an adventure game without dialogue at all, the plot is quite memorable and involving, with the characters having both impact and personality.  By removing dialogue from the game, the designers also allow the game to be accessible to players who do not speak English, using thought bubbles and pictures, authentic instruments and short beeps or buzzes to illustrate what characters are thinking or asking.Puzzles throughout the game are both thought-provoking and challenging, sometimes requiring the player to think outside the box to complete tasks without pushing for weird feats of skewed logic present in some games of the genre.  Should the game prove to be too much of a bother, an in-built 'hint' system allows players to get some suggestions to how they can complete the task.The BadFor some players, the puzzles will be a bit too challenging, though thankfully a short minigame can help to unlock the puzzles if you are more of a mind to do a reflexive shooter than a point-and-click puzzle solve.Some players have reported having issues with transferring the game from fullscreen to windowed mode, though this seems to be more of a UI confusion than a bug issue.The UglyNone to speak of.SuggestionsTurn out the lights and enjoy the immersive, imaginative world.The SummaryWell deserving of the awards it has recieved, Machinarium is a beautiful game with something special for art and music lovers, as well as fans of the point-and-click puzzle genre.  10/10.---If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Machinarium was the first video game I've ever played, so I like to look at it as the start of my adventure behind the computer screen.I think I was around 13 at the time. We didn't have a console or gameboy at home and the only previous contact I had had with games happened when I went to my friend's place to play FIFA on his PS2. I remember there was only one computer in my place and it was my dad's work laptop. We barely ever touched it. One day my father came home with a usb pen which he took from a colleague by mistake. It had this game inside (probably an illegal copy). After having finished it, my dad gave me and my younger sisters permission to use his laptop to play Machinarium. He even encouraged us to play it, sort of like when he tried to convince us to read good books. This on itself tells a lot about the game, considering how conservative my father used to be when it came to video games.Anyway, from then on we started gathering in front of the computer screen every day to play the game one hour each time. It was everyone's favourite part of the day. Everyone looked forward to the time just before dinner when my father used to get home. He'd open the laptop, launch the game and we'd all get absorbed by these hand-drawn scenarios, the adorable robots and the fascinating music. Eventually my mom joined in and soon this became something we'd do as a family every day (we're five). Can you imagine five people in front of a laptop playing a point-and-click game? Ye, it's as weird as it sounds.The interesting part is my parents don't even like video games or technology in general. They are bookworms more than anything else and for instance they are heavily against my usage of the PC for entertainment. But somehow... somehow this game captivated them. Somehow they were able (more like eager) to spend an hour of their busy lives to take part in this adventure. And the fact that I was able to immerse myself in this masterpiece together with my parents and sisters, makes me look back at this time of my life with fondness and gratitude. Fondness towards the fact that this game united my family and brought us closer together. And gratitude towards my father for having introduced me to video games in the best way possible... through a game with an amazingly well-written storyline, beautiful and charming visuals, a stunningly atmospheric ost (one of the best soundtracks I've heard) and challenging/clever puzzles. This game will always have a special place in my heart and I couldn't recommend it more.PS: I eventually bought this game on Humble Bundle to support the devs but I haven't played it since.PS2: I find it funny that the trigger that started my video game adventure 6 years ago was pulled by my parents, who were so against this kind of stuff to start with. Little did they know...

content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												Don't you ever say this is a kids' game.Because it is not.Machinarium, in fact, is a great standalone from Amanita Design, a game development studio I am very proud of being from the same country as I am. It's a point-and-click adventure game about Machinarium - an ancient city of robots. You take control of Joseph, a robot thrown out of the city and dumped for untold reasons, and you'll lead him trough hours of great drawing and animations, story great yet simply told and soundtrack that you just have to love and admire as he makes his way back to the top, rescues his "girlfriend" Bertha, saves the city and escapes from it.Point-and-click adventures are highly relying on their story, yet this game doesn't feature a single line of text (exception to main menu and credits). Instead, it explains it with simple comics which appear in classical speech bubbles. This adds to a feeling of really being a robotic being that doesn't need any words to explain it's thoughts, even though I don't believe the creation such a feeling would be truly intentional in it's nature.The gameplay is simple as well, featuring locations with several puzzles and riddles you need to complete in order to advance further trough the city and the story. However, they aren't in any way dumb or repetetive, and can provide several hours of fun for those who enjoy solving these. And if you don't, the game always has a helpful guide for the location you can unlock trough fulfilling a simple minigame.The graphics and design are the most awesome things about this game, providing you with beautiful sceneries, impecable characters and detailed drawings of the city and it's parts all along your path to the top. The city looks industrial and mechanical, creating a kind of a depressing feeling, with rust and metal pipes everywhere. The graphics are a true art, and that is not a statment I make lightly. Same of course goes for the soundtrack, so get ready to stay looking at the scenery and listening to a music, balancing at the edge of falling into depression or starting maniacally laughing. The feel is something many "horror games" of today miss - and yet this game doesn't even have to try to achieve it.So my recommendation is simple - Go for it.

Posted: January 8, 2016
												Machinarium is point & click adventure set in beautiful world of robots. Game is not easy. Difficulty is set in a way that even smart people need to think hard to complete game without help. Problems are logical enough and you need to use your imagination a bit. Logic mini game puzzles are probably the hardest part of the game. Some of them take a bit of time to solve. When you solve a problem reward is sense of accomplishment and moving forward in the game. If you know exactly what to do and just walk the walk, Machinarium is about 1.5 hours long. But length of a game is probably about 10 hours if you get stuck a lot and want to solve everything without help (like me). This is a beautiful game that reminds me of the best P&C titles I played for the length of years. I recommend it to everyone who is not afraid to use the gray matter between the ears :-)

PROS:+ cute story+ beautiful art style+ original atmosphere/levels+ mostly fun puzzles+ hint/advice system+ speech bubble communication+ great soundtrackCONS:- UI is a bit clunky sometimes- simple story & not much replayability- couple of annoying puzzlesComment:I remember playing this game years ago with my dad. Well, he was playing mostly, telling me what to do. Now I played it again and I have to see this game aged really well. The beautiful graphics style coupled with a great soundtrack gives you a great feel right away. There is no talking in this game but you get the whole story line just as easily via speech bubbles. But maybe this is also why some extra effort was not put into making the story and characters more detailed and less flat. Puzzles are kind of cool most of the time although there are some that were just weird to figure out.Overall it is a fantastic game with a couple of flaws which you will forgive because of the unique setting of a robot town. Recommended!

												Machinarium is a very well made puzzle game.However, the gameplay itself and the puzzle difficulty is waaaaaay to extreme for beginners/a bit experienced puzzle gamers.Most of the puzzles are not logical, and you will either have to play the little mini-game inside the game to unlock a hint, or look up a guide on the internet, because alot of these puzzles will literally break your head and poop down your neck.The style of the game is very unique and very well drawn. It is definitely nothing for casual players or unexperienced puzzle players.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												Machinarium is and adventure game from the hands of developers from Amanita design (who are my fellow countrymen) who are responsible for couple of very well accepted adventure games. Machinarium is another one of those and it can boast a very cute, original and !lovely! art followed by a very decent soundtrack.Adventures are usually a story driven games and Machinarium is no exception, though compared to other adventures it is quite exceptional. There is not a single line of text (spoken or written) and the story is narrated with the use of comics bubbles showing thoughts of characters in pictures. I would not like to spoil anything and my memory is also a little fuzzy since I have been playing the game with months worth of pauses so I will not dig deep into the story, but to outline it a little I will say at least a bit. You are a small, male robot who has been separated from his sweet robot "girlfriend" and you have to find her. To do so you have to travel through a robot town doing the usuall adventurist stuff like using and combining items.As for the art itself, as I have said, it is really cute however overally the locations and characters are actually depressing, very dark and negatively industrial. This leads to pretty mixed feelings because on one hand you admire the cuteness of the drawings, on the other you feel sorry and sad.What I cannot vouch for is the design of the puzzles. They are not insanely hard, actually you will probably be able to guess what you are supposed to do pretty fast, or that was at least my case, however the steps needed to get it done seemed pretty much random and I did often struggle with them. There is nothing more frustrating than knowing the answer and struggling with finding the right paper to write it on. Because of that I often had to resort to using the build in hint system.The hint system has two levels. Upon using the first level, your little robot will pop a thought comics bubble and give you a small hint usually pointing out what it is you should do in the current room and you are to find a way to do it yourself. This may help you, but as I have already said, figuring out what to do is not much of a problem, but how to do it, that's the question. And that is what level 2 hint is for, if you are really desperate you can use it, but in order for it to work you have to finish a small mini-game which involves navigating a key through areas and monsters in kind of a side scrolling shoot-them-up (like Space Impact on old Nokia cells). Upon finishing it (and you will probably hate every second of it, because it has terrible hitbox and is just no fun) you will be given a comics like page in a book showing you step-by-step walkthrough.So to sum up, I did like this game to an extent mainly because of the art and soundtrack. Story was good enough but I was really annoyed with puzzles and the hint system. I do recommend you to play this game, but I would say, don't feel a shame if you want to grab a hint or two, or rather get  a walkthrough on the internet (if you hate the minigame required to complete for the hint as much as I did) when you are stuck for unreasonably long time.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												It’s not often that a point and click adventure grabs my attention these days, in fact the only two that come to mind are Back to the Future and Finding Teddy, yet Machinarium had just the right charm to stand out amongst the masses and pull me in.And it’s a good thing too, because without the adorable robot/steampunkish skin, the precious animations, and fantastic soundscape, Machinarium would just be another generic point and click puzzle game. The puzzles themselves were often convoluted and some just outright infuriated me when I found out what you had to do to solve them. If I had not been so invested in this adorable little robot and watching him move around this world my game time would have ended after about 45 minutes.If you love what you see in the screenshots, and are not totally averse to the Point and Click genre then I think there’s a ton of enjoyment to be had with Machinarium. However, if you find this genre of game insufferable or don’t find the same charm in the art that I do, then steer clear because there’s nothing here that you’re not expecting.

I played a demo, then I saved for it, I loved the art, and I was determined to love it... but nope.PROS:+ Beautiful steampunk-esque artwork.+ Original setting and dialog by drawings in bubbles.CONS:- No saves... Your saves won't stay!- The puzzles aren't logical. It starts ok (I did play the demo!), but then it becomes "click on everything ad nauseam until something works", which is the worst kind of point and click ever.- That alone wouldn't be that bad (I played a lot of those...), but the steps needed for each trial and error become incredibly annoying after a while.The way the character walks slowly when you forget to put him back to "regular" size is adorable... the first hour.Now, IF you enjoy this kind of "click on random pixel hunt until something happens" games, you will love Machinarium and its really beautiful hand drawn environment.EDIT: I understand most people disagreeing with me; it's a truly beautiful game, and I see how people wouldn't find this "helpful", especially when helpful/not helpful is the only way Steam can allow us to like/dislike a review. I tried to help other buyers, rather than simply bashing the game, explaining the things I didn't like in it. And I do hope it helps!

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5
												Machinarium was, I believe, the second game I owned on Steam. Now I have 1000 games but Machinarium still holds a place in my heart. As Amanita's first full-length game, it has its flaws - Save-game issues, originally had no achievements, now it has achievements but they don't unlock. Slow, unskippable walking animations. The seemingly unescapable "click the exact pixel" puzzles. In spite of all that, Machinarium has undeniable charm and style. Beautiful art, one of my favourite video game soundtracks. Clever puzzles to accompany a gorgeous game. I think everyone should finish Machinarium at least once, which is saying something considering how many flaws I was able to list. For what Machinarium does right, it excels at.8.5/10

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Machinarium is a gorgeous point and click puzzler from Amanita Design, who have also created the wonderful Samorost series and Botanicula. Having played their other titles I can honestly tell you that Machinarium has a similarily beautiful world that you must make your way through to complete the game. The robot city you will explore in this title is extremely detailed, with emotionally moving scenescapes galore. The puzzles featured in this title are also the most challenging of Amanita's catalogue, though this is no criticism. Each puzzle is unique from the last, and will take careful consideration to solve. Just as the wold of Machinarium is complex and detailed, so to are its puzzles. I would highly recommend this title to fans of any of Amanita's work, or those who would enjoy a gorgeous and engaging puzzler to sink a few hours into.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Machinarium is a beautiful and maybe a bit short graphic adventure in which we control a nameless little robot trying to get back to its home city and learning why he got expelled from it in the first place.With a great and unique artistic style and no dialogues, Machinarium almost always manages to comunicate the player "what does he need to do next", although there are some points in the story in which the in-game help (Through both hints and a total solution for a puzzle, unlockable through a mini-game that you have to beat each time you want to check it so you don't have instant access to it) is kind of needed, as the next objective is not too clear.The puzzles are not too hard to solve, although some of them are challenging enough to get stuck on them for some time (Which is kind of the point in this type of games), and they are usually "logical" puzzles (Sliders, buttons, etc) with even some mini-games (A space invaders clone, a small top-down shooter game..) to add some variety to our little robot's adventure.Machinarium is a charming adventure game, with emphasis on logical puzzles more than in the "mix items A and B to get C to open door D" formula and an adjusted difficulty to provide a nice challenge while not making the player go crazy. A great addition to anyone's game collection.Also, I blame Amanita design for not selling a toy of the little robot :(

content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
Short version: 82%Machinarium is a textless point ‘n’ click adventure game set in a robot world with a really memorable design, difficult puzzles, and a simple, yet wonderful story.Long version:Anamita Design is famous for their adventure games where the entire story is told purely in visuals, without any voices or text. Machinarium is no exception.The game is set in a strange world, where cyberpunk-style city slums and rust heaps meet very friendly, children’s storybook-like character design and story structure. Even the story is childishly simple, from a certain degree: you are a little “boy” who must save his girlfriend from a band of good-for-nothing hoodlums. These bullies not only managed to throw him out of the city after hurting his mentor(?), but also plan to cause further havoc among the peace-loving citizens.Machinarium has an interesting difficulty curve. Initially, all scenes are self-contained puzzles, but after a while it switches to traditional point ‘n’ click format. You suddenly have a somewhat decent-sized city to search for items you can use, but it won’t be easy. The world is quite alien despite the somewhat human-like elements, and there are no descriptions anywhere. This can make identifying objects quite tricky sometimes, so prepare to resort to some brute force trial and error.Despite the difficulty, the game is surprisingly short; if you start it up again knowing all the solutions, you can enjoy the full story in about two hours. As an Anamita game this length is pretty much expected, and you can know that you get a sweet, fun and charming little gem– with a memorable soundtrack– for your money.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
Machinarium is a 2D click-and-point adventure with a charming story, amazing lovingly drawn backgrounds and a wonderfully completing soundtrack. The game’s atmosphere immediately touches the heart and the whole concept is quite inspiring. It’s somehow a mix of Salvador Dalí and an enchanted picture book. The puzzles are not easy yet not too hard, especially because the game helps, if one hasn’t any clue of what to do – and even this help is embedded in a nice mini-game. Overall it’s clear: the game is created by heart and not by financial thoughts. I recommend this game to anyone but children – even if the story may suit a child’s fantasy, the puzzles are not, because of their difficulty. The game is slow-paced yet interesting and is a good match for people who are new to this genre as well as for point-and-click fans. Machinarium is a fantastic game.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												I had a ton of fun playing this game! The art, animations and music are all great and although it didn't have any dialouge the story was still conveyed nicely through thought bubbles and pictures. Most of the puzzles are pretty easy and straight forward, but I found the last three (bead, robot brain and sound puzzles) to be the most difficult and they may cause some trouble for first time Point n' Click players. Overall I'd give it 9/10Be advised that unlike most other Point n' Click games the robot has to be near an object to ineract with it, you aren't able to click on things from across the room and have him walk to and activate it.Here's a link to the demo incase you want to give a go before purchasing.http://machinarium.net/demo/

content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												Superb, my new favorite point & Click game.Its polish as ♥♥♥♥ simply put. There is a mix between point&Click action puzzles and standard table puzzles;Both of them are amazing, the table style puzzles are challenging and original from my knowledge, I saw some of them as classic, but the rest was fresh. I love the way you are pourring good around you, its simple but it works.The design is exellent, some shapes ring memory from the Neverhood. Every objects are oddly shaped and cool (the long arcade TV to the round radio). Art is Beautiful and gritty at the same time, from far the lighting looks real o.0Most of the rooms have different ambient music, it even place a foot inside the experimental genre.My black spots are ; The game frame dont take advantage of all of my screen, I know the game use a room position into the gameplay, but at least make the big rooms not so small on my screen.I got lag if I dont tell windows 7 to put the program on front, in the task manager.The minigame where you must kill all the little red robots have two issues: The control is bad and the red robots tend to get stuck, blocking the player from advancing.Near the end some of the puzzles get really tricky, mostly due to the expand of the play zone, however at the beginning the play zone is really small so even if the puzzle is tricky, the solution is near your feet.Nevertheless, anything else; The gameplay, the level design, the music, the visual, the story even if simple... is exellentAnd stretchy squashy your lil robot as fast as possible never get ol !

content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												Artistic Score: 9.5/10Gameplay Score: 9.5/10Overall Score: 9.5/10Machinarium is a highly atmospheric point and click sci-fi adventure game. The game's creepy but also eerily beautiful art sets it apart from other games and makes it a totally unique and engrossing experience. The difficulty is well balanced; challenging but completely doable.Pros:+Beautiful art that really takes you into another world. The paintings in this game have so much character. Together with the music it feels deeply atmospheric and it's a great experience.+Nice soundtrack that fits perfectly with the game.+Excellent gameplay. Great puzzles with the perfect difficulty; challenging enough that I was racking my brains but not impossible. Occasional minigames also enhance the experience.+A simple story that, through the atmosphere created by the art and music, is told beautifully and seamlessly.Cons:-The game doesn't support right click, which would be a really nice way to let the player send items back to the inventory. Right now right clicking yeilds an "about Adobe Flash Player" tab, which slightly cheapens the look of the game, which is so beautiful otherwise.As a side note it took me about 7 hours to beat the game.This game is so perfect, so beautiful, that there's no reason why anyone on Earth shouldn't experience it for themselves. I can't stress it enough; this is really one that you have to play to experience.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
												Machinarium is one of those cute little Indie designs that, due to it's small team or low budget, has to pick up its boots and survive on its charm alone, and while concise and simplistic, it does that in spades. A sombre meander through a beautifully stylized, decaying robotic and alien world.HighlightsThe reason Machinarium works so well is that it's very simple, what would normally be a flat flash game has been given life with tone, interaction, soundtrack and art style all marrying together to create a truly solid little game.* The lack of dialogue and the fantastic sound and music, when placed together with the rustic, dystopian art really give the world a strong but still alien character to the world and make you want to explore and see more of it* Little detailed works like the mini-games for hints add a fun layer of light wonderMistakes* Genuinely none that take away from the game other than perhaps a lacklustre endingRecommendationsPlay time clocks in at 5 hours, and there are better indie titles out there for less than Machinarium, and with more replay value, of which Machinarium has very little, but at £7.49/8.49€/$9.99, it's still a reasonably priced and is a good buy when on sale.There's also an Amanita Collection, which matches the prices of the separate games, but adds the value of the Machinarium soundtrack for free, but since it's soothing and ambient, but not a particularly amazing soundtrack, buying the titles separately is going to be the better choice for most.* There's a free demo available on the store page* You can play Samorost (a previous flash title by Amanita) on their website for free[amanita-design.net]* [spoler]The bricks with the spiders in the hint-book sometimes spell out the word rebol..[/spoiler] ..if you type "rebol" on the start screen you will gain access to a developer menu where you can select all levels and access all items* There's was a limited edition Machinarium Fan Edition[forum.amanita-design.net] which may still be available on Amazon

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												This is probably my new favorite adventure game. It's beautiful, charming, funny, and very clever.I had played the App Store version most of the way through, and it still took some thinking to redo the puzzles in the Steam copy. One of the most challenging puzzles is near the beginning of the game, so if the first few areas don't seem too bad, you won't need to resort to a guide.There was only one puzzle whose solution seemed a bit arbitrary and illogical (it has to do with a bird...), and I admit to figuring it out by accident. Other than that one example, I really appreciated the intuitive design of every other single element in the game, which made the puzzle solving a pleasant experience even while I was scratching my head or "stuck". I also played this with no less than three non-gamers, and they all enjoyed getting into it as much as I did.I have read many people complaining about the game's length, saying it took 6-8 hours on average while using the in-game guide for the tougher puzzles. I am a decent puzzle solver (not great), and it easily netted me 10 hours of gameplay time without using a guide at all. That having been said, knowing the solutions can make a speed run of an hour or two very easy.Machinarium is innovative and brilliant, and I like it.8/10

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												An "indie" game from before they were cool, Machinarium combines creative point and click tasks with excellent puzzles that briefly pop you out of the point and click interface to solve problems similar to classic real world mind benders like unhook the horeshoe/nails puzzle (but not that).  It wraps all this up in an immersive world of decrepit technology and cute little sentient robots.  One thing that works well in this game is the complete absence of dialog.  And I don't mean just spoken dialog - there is no spoken or written language at all.  The story and game progression is communicated through hand drawn diagrams and trail and error.  The game is entirely in flash, so your controls are usually limited to left mouse button and mouse movement.  Although, the game has a built in hint system comprised of a very short SHMUP sequence that allows you to use the keyboard.  Strangely an end game action sequence forced me to use mouse control which was the only real point where I experienced significant frustration while playing the game.Overall, this game is easy to recommend even at full price.  The puzzles are challenging but not frustrating and the pace of self discovery is excellent for a point and click game.  The art style really makes you feel like you are discovering a new world, and invites you to participate in it with its quirky characters.

												If you like indie point-and-click games with detailed quirky graphics, challenging (and often frustrating) puzzles, and loveable characters all set to the soundtrack that would make a techno minimalist ♥♥♥♥♥♥, this is the game for you. Machinarium starts off a bit rough around the edges, you don't really care for your main character nor understand what his goal in the game is. But that's just the best part. The amazing thing is, without ANY dialogue, you start to become concerned for him as you start to overcome obstacles. In short the pros:- great 2D graphics- character development and plot- for $3.49 this game entertained me for ~5 hours and more (since I'm almost finished)- majority of puzzles are innovative- added element since main character can adjust himself to be taller/shorter- hints and walkthrough provided by game (you just have to work for them)cons:- HOLY CRAP some of the puzzles get hard and redundant- you walk really freaking slowIf I have convinced you to purchase this game, my last bit of advice would be to either 1. have patience or 2. get good at killing spiders

Posted: January 8, 2014
												I was fortunate enough to pick this game up in a bundled sale a little while ago. It was also my first experience with a point-and-click adventure game, and I have to say that it did a great job convincing me to play more in this genre. The art style is wonderful, with a rough and hand-drawn feel to the environment and characters, while important items stand out just enough to notice them without losing the immersion in each area. The setting and the story feel very rich without any words or text throughout the entire game, though sometimes it feels like you're not accomplishing anything, just finding things to click on.The puzzles in the game are varied and plenty, testing your spatial reasoning, forethought, attention to detail, and in a few cases, reaction time. While collecting items to propel the story, there are times when you'll be carrying three or four different things around, but it rarely goes past that, and figuring out which items to combine is never a struggle. Some of the obstacles actually require you to use items separately, but in conjunction with each other, which took me a good deal longer than I care to admit to figure out how it was supposed to work.There are times you'll sit in front of your computer, just thinking "I don't know what to do..." for 10 minutes, and some of the puzzles are so frustrating that you might just force your way through them instead of thinking through it; however, I don't believe those moments detract from the game that much, because even when you're wandering aimlessly, not noticing that one item sitting on the ground that would let you move on, you're still treated to a beautiful environment and great music which creates a perfect atmospheric feel to the experience.Overall, I think this game is worth playing, and I don't think $10 is too much to spend on it. There are a few thing's I would have liked different, but that might be because of my inexperience in the genre. It is a challenging, engaging game that will give you 3-6 hours of fun the first time through. The biggest issue for me is replay value, and a second time through will let you focus on the story instead of the puzzles, which I consider a good enough reason to play again.

Posted: March 8, 2014
												Machinarium is a point-and-click adventure game with heavy use of puzzles and brain teasers. It’s created by Amanita Design, a small, independent game developing studio based in the Czech Republic. The game was released in 2009, but that something is “old” doesn’t necessarily mean that it’s bad. “Old” in this case means that us patient gamers can get it on sale. “Old” in this case also means that the game is written in Flash, but we’ll come back to that later. Machinarium tells the story about Josef, a little robot who finds himself dumped on a scrapheap. After re-assembling himself he sets off towards the city to look for a friend. The story, which is told without the use of text or dialogue, unfolds as you play, and even though it’s not the most intriguing and creative story I’ve seen – you’ll probably feel it’s very familiar – it’s very well told.The story’s backdrop is beautiful, hand-drawn scenes accompanied to a lovely soundtrack by Floex, Amanita Design’s own in-house “sound maker”, as he is entitled on their website. The soundtrack is available here[store.floex.cz] if you want to listen to it. If I’d have to label it, I’d call it “industrial chill”, which is perfect for Machinarium – except for some plants and a bit of water, everything in the game is mechanized and industrial, including the local wild life. The game design is extraordinary well thought-through and the attention to detail is impressive.The puzzles you stumble across in Machinarium are mostly about pattern recognition. How to interact with the environment is also often part of the puzzles, which are very well balanced and just challenging enough for Average Joe. I got stuck once, but even if that happens, there is hope. Josef will have a small clue for you most of the time and if you find yourself feeling like an idiot for not being able to solve a puzzle even with his help, you can play a little mini-game that will reveal the solution, or at least give you some very good clues on how to solve it.But Machinarium, like all games, has its flaws. The game is written in Flash, and clicking the right mouse button brings up the Flash menu with its “About Flash” and whatnot. Since clicking the right mouse button is usually some kind of action in other point-and-click adventure games – for instance that you automatically put whatever you are holding back in to your inventory – the Flash menu got a bit annoying after a while. It’s mostly my own fault though, for not being able to memorize that I could not use the right mouse button to return whatever the little robot was holding in his hand back to the inventory. Instead the inventory had to be opened before the item could be returned. Point-and-click adventure games often involves a lot of pointing and clicking – hence the genre’s name – with items from the inventory, a process that got rather tedious.The game lagged considerably on my computer when played in fullscreen. It have to be said that my hardware isn’t what you would call state of the art, but it should be able to handle a game from 2009. Hardware acceleration was turned on in the Flash settings, but that didn’t help at all. I ended up playing the game in windowed mode, which worked a lot better and was fine since fullscreen didn’t really add anything to the game: The resolution used in both fullscreen and window mode is the same. The immense detail of the background images also proved to be a challenge: In one of the scenes, it was virtually impossible to see that the main character could interact with an object on the screen, and it was only by accident I clicked on it.But in spite of these minor issues, Machinarium is a great game. If you like puzzle games and brain teasers, you should go right ahead and buy it. It won’t entertain you that long, it took me only 6 hours to complete the game and I really suck at puzzles, but at the asking price of USD 10 it’s certainly worth it.This review is also available on http://www.vegard.net/.

												If you like indie point-and-click games with detailed quirky graphics, challenging (and often frustrating) puzzles, and loveable characters all set to the soundtrack that would make a techno minimalist ♥♥♥♥♥♥, this is the game for you. The amazing thing is, without ANY dialogue, you start to become concerned for him as you start to overcome obstacles. In short the pros:- great 2D graphics- character development and plot- for $3.49 this game entertained me for ~5 hours and more (since I'm almost finished)- majority of puzzles are innovative- added element since main character can adjust himself to be taller/shorter- hints and walkthrough provided by game (you just have to work for them)cons:- HOLY CRAP some of the puzzles get hard and redundant- you walk really freaking slowIf I have convinced you to purchase this game, my last bit of advice would be to either 1. have patience or 2. get good at killing spiders

Posted: March 5, 2014
												Before point and click adventures never interested me. They seemed boring with their lack of action and their settings were always something i could find in a more interesting game. Machinarium changed that. I still prefer action titles but Machinarium had the unique charm i had heard about. Not too easy, not too hard, i loved it. The story telling was superb and the atmosphere was unlike any other game I've played. This nameless robot had wedged himself into my heart and is now one of my favorite video game characters, from one of my most memorable games, with one of the most memorable adventures.This game is ABSOLUTELY worth the full price!

Posted: January 8, 2014
												I was fortunate enough to pick this game up in a bundled sale a little while ago. It was also my first experience with a point-and-click adventure game, and I have to say that it did a great job convincing me to play more in this genre. The art style is wonderful, with a rough and hand-drawn feel to the environment and characters, while important items stand out just enough to notice them without losing the immersion in each area. The setting and the story feel very rich without any words or text throughout the entire game, though sometimes it feels like you're not accomplishing anything, just finding things to click on.The puzzles in the game are varied and plenty, testing your spatial reasoning, forethought, attention to detail, and in a few cases, reaction time. While collecting items to propel the story, there are times when you'll be carrying three or four different things around, but it rarely goes past that, and figuring out which items to combine is never a struggle. Some of the obstacles actually require you to use items separately, but in conjunction with each other, which took me a good deal longer than I care to admit to figure out how it was supposed to work.There are times you'll sit in front of your computer, just thinking "I don't know what to do..." for 10 minutes, and some of the puzzles are so frustrating that you might just force your way through them instead of thinking through it; however, I don't believe those moments detract from the game that much, because even when you're wandering aimlessly, not noticing that one item sitting on the ground that would let you move on, you're still treated to a beautiful environment and great music which creates a perfect atmospheric feel to the experience.Overall, I think this game is worth playing, and I don't think $10 is too much to spend on it. There are a few thing's I would have liked different, but that might be because of my inexperience in the genre. It is a challenging, engaging game that will give you 3-6 hours of fun the first time through. The biggest issue for me is replay value, and a second time through will let you focus on the story instead of the puzzles, which I consider a good enough reason to play again.

												This is a point-and-click puzzle solving game where unlike the most popular FPS games, there aren't enemies to shoot at and you can't die...  However, it is still a LOT of fun!The graphics are for the most part still backgrounds but they are quite beautiful. Posted: December 11, 2014
												Will give a more detailed account below. For now, general informationThe Good --   - Good Aesthetic -- It looks nice, and it creates a very mellow atmosphere. The art style fits well.   - Intersting puzzles -- The puzzles are fun and challanging, with only a few that I would call bad   - Interesting story -- The narrative of the game is fun, interesting, and fairly light hearted. It's also kid friendly   - Good Hint system -- Both hint systems in the game are good in their own right. The Bad -- (mostly nitpicking)   - Same old adventure game problems -- has many of the problems old adventure games had          - Some puzzles have odd solutions, goals can be a bit random, trial and error, and backtracking a thing you missed.   - Some puzzles are hard to contextualize -- making the sequence of events occur correctly to get something can be tedious and hard to figure out. Not in a logistical way, more in a, "how was i supposed to know the object would do that?" way.   - No verbal communication can mean confusion as to what the game wants, which forces you to use both hint systems.   - Moving some objects will force you to follow through with the action. When you misclick, this can mean waiting 40 or so seconds before you can do what you were supposed to do. In a few cases, this would also reset a puzzle and force you to do it again.   - Some of the background noises grate on the ears a bit. Not a game i would recommend with headphones on.   - The controls are much more fitting a touchpad then a PCFull thoughts --This game was fun. Not the best thing I've ever played, and certainly nothing new. The art design is interesting, but everything else has been seen and done before. This isn't a bad thing, however, as the game delivers on what it promises. It's a puzzle game with no verbal feedback. The story is simple; you solve puzzles, move forward, and right the wrongs brought about by some bullies. You save a girl you know, and help the citizens who are bummed for one reason or another. It's a simple story, especially by adventure game standards, but it delivers on some really good puzzles and explaining everything without a word of spoken dialogue.The gameplay is point and click gameplay combined with puzzle solving. It's fairly standard and familiar, but still challanging. Mostly, you walk into a room, collect objects, and solve puzzles in the room to find more or allow for objects to interact with one another. In most cases it's easy to deduce what to do and where to start, though there are a few instances where you will resort to the hint systems to see what the game wants you to do. As for the hint systems, there are actually two in this game. One is a one per screen type of deal. It will rarely tell you what you do next, so much as what you need to accomplish in the room. Sometimes that's enough, but if you need more help there's a second option. There is a wallet that will let you play a short mini-game. After beating the mini-game, you will be shown (with pictures and diagrams, which are great for puzzle solutions) everything you need to do within that room. It won't show you how to get objects in other rooms, but it will show you if you need an object you don't yet have to complete a puzzle. This takes a lot of frustration out of the puzzling, and gives you a place to go if you don't have a clue and don't want to resort to a walkthrough.As for the port, it isn't great. I mentioned some aspects are build for a touchpad, and this is true. There are some puzzles whos parts are a bit unresponsive, or work poorly with a mouse. Other parts work just fine or better. Some puzzles integrate keyboard keys (though they don't every tell you which keys will work and for what), and it's generally self explainitory as to which keys to use (the arrow keys and spacebar are the most common when they can be used). You cannot rebind keys (though you can play entirely with the mouse), and there are few options. Adjusting your options is very easy, however, as they're at the bottom of the screen if you mouse over them. The port is what you would expect of a game ported from a tablet. Not bad, but not very good either.My opinion --I enjoyed the game. It was a short and fun puzzle adventure game that didn't overstay it's welcome. I felt like only one or two puzzles were bad, but none of them were game breaking or too frustrating. I really liked the hint system in this game, as it ment I never needed a walkthrough. If the puzzle solution was rediculous or too tough, you can find the solution ingame (even if getting to the second hint system is a bit tedious). Most Adventure games have a few points where they lose the player, usually because they didn't know they missed something, or that they simply can't progress yet and have to go to a new area to get a new item to get futher. This hint system lets you get over that hump, so that frustration is kept to a minimum. Most of the problems i have with the game are nitpicks, with no really bad things to say. If you like puzzle games, and don't mind a little UI fiddliness, this game is great.Overall, buy it if you like adventure games, puzzle games, or mellow games that don't stress you out. Also, decent game for getting the brain working after so many years out of school =)

Regardless of whether you'd prefer to think through the puzzles or skip through them to get to each area, the game is worth your time and your money. An absolute timeless classic.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												I knew and admired Amanita Design ever since the first Samorost webgame, and Samorost 2 was a great sequel, so when they came out with Machinarium, their first full-length game, I expected nothing less than something great. But what I discovered was far above all my expectations. With seemingly simple tools in a 2d world, Czech artist Jakub Dvorský and his team create a live, beautiful and magically strange world with so much detail you'll want to explore every pixel of it, and you will be well rewarded to do so.Characters are colourful and charming, interactions are fun, puzzles interesting, animations fluid, each location is wonderfully detailed, and a touching little story is told without a single spelled word. Great sound design adds layers to the atmosphere, and the music... Well, the music just sticks with you. To this day, every time I turn on the OST by Tomáš Dvořák I still get those magical chills.This game is a 100% proof that videogame design is/can/should be an art. PS> very enjoyable with a girlfriend, wife or kids.

Posted: July 1, 2016
Machinarium: 10/10A little robot who's been thrown out of the city and into the scrap yard must battle his way back into the city to save his robot-girl friend."Hold it. Hold it. What is this? Are you trying to trick me? Where's the sports? Is this a kissing story?"Joking aside, this game is so much fun to play and it's probably one of the best point and click adventure games that I've ever played. The story is great, the puzzles are a little challenging (nothing that you can't figure out with a little bit of time or a pen and paper), and the music/atmosphere is beautiful. It's a fairly short game that took me about 5-6 hours to beat, but it was still worth it. If you liked this one, be sure to check out their other games :)My name is robot. You kidnapped my robot-girl friend. Prepare to die.Good luck and have fun!

												A great example of a modern version of a dated genre. This game is very much like Myst - you're dropped in a strange world with little story and little direction, and some of the puzzles are nigh-inscrutable. The modernization comes from the game's unique and cool help system, which will let you progress through the game with as much or as little help as you want, and you'll *never* need an outside walkthrough. Recommended!

content:
Posted: September 14, 2011
												Machinarium is a groovy little adventure game. The puzzles are not too difficult, and fairly logical... you rarely have that awful adventure-game experience where you're moving from room to room, clicking on random stuff, trying to get lucky. The game starts you out slow - one room, one puzzle, and gradually works you up to several rooms with several simultaneous puzzles.The overall atmosphere is very good... a little robot exploring a run-down robot city. And the sound is fantastic, with a variety of full-length songs and themes for each area you explore.There's very little not to like, here. The length of this game is about 6-8 hours. Maybe a little less if you're an adventure game junkie. Overall, Machinarium is a finely-tuned gem.

content:
Posted: January 1
												6/10. I have very mixed feelings about this game, because the good things about it are very good and the bad things about it are very bad. Especially noteworthy on the bad side is the fact that I had a hard time getting the game to work right in the first place. The game warns you to adjust your flash settings (right click and disable hardware acceleration), and I did indeed have to do that, but it wasn't enough. I went through several variations of display problems and malfunctioning mouse input before I finally got it to work by messing with Windows compatibility settings. So, it took me 30 minutes just to start playing the gameOnce you get into it, the game is fun. The art style and animation are really something special, and made me smile frequently throughout the game. It also has some of the best logic puzzles I have seen in an adventure game. Most of them are challenging but fair. Of course, like most adventure games, it does have a few moments of "How was I supposed to know that?" or "I was stuck because I didn't even see that object!" It gets frustrating at times. There is a minigame that you can play to get hints if you are stuck, which is a great idea. Unfortunately, the minigame isn't actually fun and becomes a chore after the first couple of times. Cute idea, bad execution, and it adds to the frustration when that's the last thing you need. Also, the controls are awkward, even for a point-and-click game.It's a really tough call to recommend this game or not. I'm going with "No" because I think most people would not enjoy this kind of experience, especially with the technical difficulties. I can understand why it has its fans, and I did enjoy it sometimes, but it's just too much of a mixed bag for me to recommend buying it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												This is a game about a robot trying to save a friend/girlfriend, It's only weapon is it's intelligence so you'll have to solve plenty of puzzles and also help many other robots along your way if you want to succeed in this great point-and-click game. It has amazing artwork and a beautiful, haunting soundtrack that sets the mood just right and sinergizes very well with the artwork. The game designers opted to not have any writing or voice acting whatsoever, telling all the story through animated baloons that show what happened, or what people want.  It also has a built-in visual walktrhough that you have to play a mini game every time you have to access and also doesn't tell you everything, but it can be refreshing for when you don't know what to do and leaves you feeling a little less of a cheater than reading an actual walktrhough It also is very linear and provides only one answer to the puzzles so you may find yourself using this walkthrough more than you'd like, but that's actually a characteristic of most video-games and of point and click in particular. In my opinion, I found that all in all the game tells a light and heartwarming tale of courage and love and leaves you with a smile afterwards, managing to get you satisfied with all that puzzle solving when you see the result of all that hard work.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												Machinarium is an alternate universe puzzle point and click adventure in which you play as a small robot known as Josef who is looking for his missing girlfriend Berta. The adventure starts with you laying in a scrapheap figuring out how to piece yourself together. And once you get past that little puzzle, you quickly realise this is not an easy game... The puzzles are definitely more inline with the difficultly of the 16bit area of video gaming, not that it is a bad thing thing. The difficulty of the game naturally fits in with the aesthetics of the art, one can spend so long on certain puzzles, it gives plenty of time to admire the sheer beauty of the hand drawn art. The puzzles are creative and fresh, with a strong touch of quirkiness and humour with every completion. The music is easy on the ears and integrates with the games deep atmosphere. My criticisms of Machinarium would be that pointer can be a little imprecise, also if you move Josef while he is in tall or shot form, he hobbles along at a tedious pace. And the game does not offer any video settings, on certain monitors it can appear 'boxed'. Besides these minor setbacks, Machinarium is a beautiful work of art and a solid puzzle game full of humour, unique surprises and character. I strongly recommend this one.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												Great atmosphere, for a simple point and click. It draws you in with a well done sound track and surprisingly good character development. The puzzles range from relatively simple to fairly complex. The help system is a nice addition, as the developers must have realized that if people got stuck they would just go to the internet. Although being able to get hints before the solution would have been preferred. The penalty for looking at the solution is taking the time to play a short mini game, which is much better than other games simply having a countdown timer. The length decent, it tells it's story without rushing or overstaying it's bounds.  Simply put, I absolutely adore this game and would recommend it to anyone.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2012
												Top-notch point-and-click adventure with beautifully drawn 2D environments. You begin as a robot in a scrap heap putting yourself back together. Your mission is to rescue your girlfriend and the story is charming, with minimal text and characters' memories and thoughts played out through animated comic bubbles. Combined with a perfect atmosphere, you'll easily be immersed in the mechanical world. As far as how it plays, you do actually walk around and, when you find useful objects in the environment and click on them, you will either use them or eat them, which places them into your inventory to be used later. You can also stretch yourself vertically and will need to utilize that ability to solve certain puzzles. While there is some hidden object, the game is light on it; it's more a puzzle adventure and figuring out what you need to do on a few screens at a time to progress. A good variety of puzzle types and minigames. Sketch hints available if you're stumped. Highly recommended.

But my monitor runs at  2560x1440 and the game just fills a small portion of the screen with a huge black border all the way around,  Running in windows mode simply runs in a window without the black borders, running in full screen simply keeps the window the same size and adds a huge black border.The suggested solution is to change my desktop resolution which I dont want to do  (and shouldnt have to do) jjust to play one game.I tried setting it at 1024x768 just to try and there was still a gap all round.That is the only reason I'm giving it a thumbs down. Many people have large resolution monitors and shouldnt have to alter from their native display resolution just to play one gameNeeds to say what resolution it runs at and that you cant change it

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Well I guess I'll start by saying if steam had something between yes and no I would have picked that.I wanted to like this game, but I found it hard to.Pros:- Well I like the graphics, so I'll call that a pro- A variety of puzzles to solve- A happy ending, I think at least.Cons:- I prefer the keyboard (obviously I am fine using the mouse for point and click games), and two of the mini games let me use that, the third didn't and was also the most annoying thing in the game to control.- The sound fx and music, I didn't hear much, but what was there was just...not great.- The biggest con for me was not having a clue what I was suppose to do. Clicking the hint button is a waste of time, because it shows you a picture of what you are trying to accomplish, which for most of the game you can find out easily by talking to the NPCs, and doesn't help if your stuck, have an empty inventory, and no clue what strange things you need to find, or do, to accomplish the task.- The second biggest con for me was lack of zooming in on some things that you need to see. I played in full screen mode yet some of the things opened up in reletively small windows. Personally I hate having to put my face next to my screen to see important things in games.That's about all I can think of to mention. In my opinion it isn't a bad game, it's just not a great game either. I guess I just expected better because of all the good reviews.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
Don't be fooled by my time on record! I finished this game on a different Steam account.I have rarely seen a Point & Click Adventure with such beautiful art style and such a cute story.Machinarium is quite difficult, so you can spend some time beating it while avoiding frustration in a novelty way. It has walktrough-type hints built in which you need to solve a little minigame for each time to access. This keeps you from cheating yourself by giving up too quickly while still allowing you to check the puzzles' solutions when you're stranded, in a fun way.

Posted: October 25, 2011
												Machinarium's an interesting adventure game that I was worried I wouldn't like because it looked almost too simple. I came to find out it's surprisingly difficult, with puzzles that are deviously clever and will legitimately challenge your brain throughout.  There's a surprising amount of charm in this little gem as well, though at times I was left scratching my head a bit when it came to the storyline. Still, if you're an adventure game fan, definitely check it out.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2011
												Very cute little point-and-click game, really enjoyable to play. Unlike typical adventure games where you have complex storylines and lots of talking with other characters, this one has all speech reduced to the form of simple animations showing what the characters you're talking to want. It also has a simple storyline that becomes clearer as you progress. So if you're not a fan of complex adventures with lots of talking, you might still enjoy playing this one. It has plenty of little puzzles to solve and they're nice. It's not a very long game (but I wouldn't say it's too short either) and it's probably a one-time fun, but there's nothing to regret. I finished, I enjoyed, I recommend.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												This game is a masterpiece. It's cute, it's funny, it's beautiful, it's engaging, but most of all it's thoroughly entertaining.It's so rare to come across a flawless game like this that I'm actually lost for words. There are literally no faults, just a list of things that were done well or adequately. There were no frivolous attempts at reinventing the wheel - saving works the old fashioned way, as does returning from the dead. I don't think level of perfection was an accident either. The game openly invites you to glare at it, to scrutinize, looking for clues, to scan every inch of the screen admiring the attention to detail. The features have been pared down to the very barebones required for function, leaving nothing to distract from the overall experience.The main character and protagonist is a big standout for me. He's hilarious, adorable, and instantly likeable. Everything from his little dance to the way he "speaks" fills my heart with joy. It's not often that I find myself so attached to the player character, so I was pleasantly surprised by this.The music and artwork/level design is simply beautiful. The OST was written by notable IDM artist, Floex, who was also responsible for the soundtrack to Samarost. These two game elements come together in perfect harmony to create a uniquely atmospheric world that gave me a limbic response I haven't felt since playing the Oddworld series.The humour is organic, witty, and sometimes quite subtle. The game strikes a great balance between comedy and serious themes. When it's not being funny, the storyline explores loss, loneliness, depression, addiction, reunion, family, and various other themes with tact and sensitivity. There is never "too much" of any one emotion, so that the game remains enjoyable without straying into being overwhelming. This level of emotional balance is, in my opinion, unparalleled.The storyline flows extremely well - there are no side quests, instead the game takes a seemingly meandering course through all characters and areas. Sometimes it can take a while to figure out a puzzle, while others are relatively straightforward. The nice thing about this is, the game works a bit like an IQ test in the sense that it will test your weaknesses as well as your strengths. It's puzzles run the gamut and no puzzle is repeated - some gamers will find a section hard, while others will find it easy. Your mileage will truly vary.Finally, I want to add that after finishing this game I felt like my life had been enriched having played it. I felt like I was better off, like I had taken a cultural-tour holiday, or been to a museum. This game is wholesome and good for the soul. If none of the other things I've said have encouraged you to buy and play it, but you've been feeling a little blue lately, here's my advice: Take one Machinarium and call me in the morning.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
 Best Point & Click I've ever playedI don't normally play point and click games as its not a popular genre in this day and age but for this I'd make an exception. Machinarium is a truly enjoyable experience with relatable and interesting characters and an incredible world that suits the atmosphere and story perfectly. PuzzlesVery challenging and really push your puzzle solving abilities to the limit. If you find one to be to hard there's tips and even a walk through book that requires you to beat a small mini game to access.StoryTypical story of the small unexpected hero who goes above and beyond to save the girl from the bad guys and save the day but with robots!9.7/10 - Best Point and click game I've ever played, Amazing atmosphere that feels fresh and believable for the setting. Only downside is its a bit short, only 3-4 hours of gameplay

												A highly enjoyable point and click adventure.Our friendly protagonist robot sets out to rescue his robot girlfriend from a group of thugs that has kidnapped her. He must make his way into and through a large robot city full of quirks and strange contraptions, and along the way solve puzzles and help other robots to gain their help.While the game appeals to all ages, the puzzles are quite hard at times, though ingeniously made without involving math, text, etc, and we must rely on logic, memory and observation. If the player is having trouble continuing, there are tools to help.Its not a long game, but very funny, beautiful and rewarding when you solve a hard section.Highly recommendable!

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19
												Machinarium is some kind of hidden object, point and klick and puzzle game. You control a tiny robot, who's protecting robo city and rescuing his girlfriend at the same time. The story develops nicely during the gameplay, but falls somewhat short in the end. It is painted quite nicely, and the complexity of the game expands well with it's length. The puzzles, in the endgame, become sometimes very difficult (like moving boxes in a 16 step solution). I personally prefer the puzzle mechanics in portal or thalos, but If your ok with a) guessing or b) thinking alot, (or c) cheating) instead of smooth and uninterupted gameplay, you might like this. I would give it a thumbs up, if there wasn't: I can't save. Ok I can save, but I can not load. This happens, following google, to many others and is caused by that crappy saving policy - it's using a macomedia's flash cookie (it's a flash game ... ).If you are like me, automatically deleting that kind of stuff, you will delete your saves too.The solution is simple: disable autoamtic flash cookie deletion. If that is not an option for you, you should consider not byuing this game.That said, it is also worth mentioning, that there actually is a version of the game that runs under linux - but that version is not available in steam.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												I played a lot lot of P&C games since my childhood being born in early 90s, so I kinda follow the genre ever since. And it took me time to get Machinarium, I wanted it!But I must say the visual appeal has unfortunatly nothing to do with the content. The first hour of discovery is alright and pretty blowing. But as I went through "riddles" and repetitiv puzzles and minigames (which represent half of the game), I found Machinarium's limit. Not only some minigames are  either difficult and unfunny to solve (they have several levels you must enforce to progress), either pointlessly easy, like fillers. But the riddles are out of logic, even in this mysterious world.The last decades have proven you can achieve to implement a sense of logic in an absurd story and lore. And Machinarium fails at it imho. You have to try every item on every interactiv npc/environnement to find your way through. It's a pixel-check game that reminds the darkest days of p&c.Then, devs have put 2 "help" tool in-game, including the solution to riddles/puzzles. Besides the gentle will of helping the customer, it tells us that devs were totally aware of the absurdity and difficulty of their own riddles. And that is unprofessional. A p&c with solution in-game, this says a lot...Lastly, the ergonomy is nowhere to be seen. In Machinarium you actually have to "go to" the item you wanna check, and only then, you can interact with it. Meanwhile most p&c do that simply by a single click on the item itself.Also when you click on a door on top of stairs, the character will go up the stairs, and once on top, what does he do?? He forgets about your command! Open the door ffs! And there are others "little details" like this that kills the gameplay and rythm of progression. That is sad. You can't double click to run, the inventory slide-thingy is not really responsive, the size of the character never resets when you move him, so he takes ages to go somewhere after interactions... We could go on. Did they play p&c before developping this at least?No I can't recommend this game for the hardcore p&c gamers. At least, never intend to beat it in a single session unless you wanna go crazy. Give it time to finish, and better be real patient. The only way to appreciate this game is by watching a playthrough of someone knowing exactly what to do.By the way, the artistic dept is great, the ost is ok. The universe is catchy and lovely, they did a good job there.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2013
												What a great creative game! This adventure puzzle game doesn't just give you puzzles to complete, but a story line. The story line may not seem very present at first, but builds up into an interesting story as you learn more and more about the character you play. These puzzles can be challenging, but the game offers a nice way to get hints and if you are really bad it will give you a walk through right there in the game if you so choose. In addition to the the great gameplay this game has an amazin sound track. I found myself sitting in the plaza listing the band play their whole song before I moved on to the next room. I highly recommend buying this game! There isn't too much in terms of replayability, but some day I may find myself coming back to it once I've forgotten the puzzles.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												A cute puzzle game with excellent aesthetics and an immersive ambient soundtrack. Worth playing just for the music alone. None of the puzzles are undoable, and are enjoyable to see play out. Some people have complained about the difficulty of figuring out the puzzles, but remember that as an animated game that it utilizes cartoon physics at times and require that you use your imagination to put together the solutions. The game can take 5-8 hours depending on your problem solving skills.The weakest part of the game is the flat, sudden ending. It was like the developer had all these interesting ideas but couldn't figure out how to tie it all together in a way which was satisfying. Nowhere near a deal breaking flaw and the game is worth it for the experience alone.

												More than anything, just a gorgeous game to play. I can't say the gameplay does much original; it's a standard point-and-click game with a few other puzzles thrown in the mix. The narrative isn't particularly unique either, though being told entirely without dialogue is perhaps an interesting spin on it. But the game world looks and sounds beautiful and the game has charm to it. The puzzles rarely get too obscure (or at least, as far as I can recall, since it's been a while since I touched this game). I can't really help but recall this one fondly, for whatever reason. It's definitely a worthy experience, though.
