number of helpful: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												Cute story, wide variety of puzzles, good art, but clumsy controls and sometimes obscure puzzles make this game sort of a wash for me. You play as a cute little robot in a point-and-click adventure with added puzzles like "move these pegs into a certain pattern" or "fill in all the lights on a grid" to help you progress to new areas of this robot-inhabited world and avoid/foil villainous robots.Pros:+Good story, despite the lack of dialogue. Everything is done with thought bubbles and grunts and sounds instead of speech. Cute.+Interesting art. Hand-drawn feel with an interesting pallete of mostly brown with splashes of muted colors here and there. The variety of robot character designs is fantastic.+Wide variety of puzzles. Not just point and click, but logic and spatial reasoning puzzles, and you even get to play Space Invaders.Cons:-There's no really good way of finding interactable items other than skimming the screen with your mouse. There were several puzzles I had to get a hint for (see below) simply because I didn't notice that tiny little item I was supposed to pick up because it was so well integrated with the art. Object highlighting in the art or a keyboard shortcut to highlight them would have greatly helped. Thus, for me, it was a steep learning curve trying to get a feel for the kinds of puzzles the designers were intending because the goal was obvious but the means of attaining that goal were obscure.-Only one pre-set hint per level, which means if you're stuck on a part that happens AFTER the hint, you're screwed. There's a way to unlock the entire solution, but it requires playing an annoying mini game first. The internet is faster, honestly.-The interface is annoying, as you can only interact with things within reach. You want to use this thing over there, so you grab it from your inventory and try to use it, but it's out of reach. Is there an easy way to put things back into your inventory? No, of course not! So then you've got to manually put it back in your inventory, which doesn't always pop up on mouseover and is hard to see because it's black, the same color as the border around the image, which is not fullscreen despite the settings. Then you've got to walk your guy over to the spot, hoping you're close enough this time, then get the item from your inventory AGAIN and use it. Very frustrating. -On a related note, there's also a mechanic where you can stretch your body up to get things high up, but sometimes you have to physically do it yourself, and other times (if it's close enough), it does it for you automatically. And if you accidentally start walking while you're stretched, God help you, because you walk around really, REALLY slowly that way, and it's hard to cancel out of a movement once it's initiated. There are ZERO puzzles where being tall while walking is needed, so the designers should have made it automatic to shrink down before attempting to walk and saved themselves some animation time and the players some frustration. And although the tutorial teaches you that you can be tall, it DOESN'T tell you that you can make yourself shorter, which is required for an early puzzle to reach an item I didn't even know could be accessed and looked like part of the background.Overall: 5/10It may be worth it for the story and the actual puzzles themselves (the non-point-and-click variety), but the frustration and amount of cheating via the internet I had to do robbed me of the joy I should have had.

number of helpful: 5 of 15 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
												It really breaks my heart to have to give this game a bad reveiw. There were clearly talented and passionate people behind it, but it just doesn't play well.Here's an example that helps to describe one of my biggest issues.-You've just broken out of your cell, and are currently in a crawl space under a room occupied by a guard, who is shooting a pellet gun of some sort at a target on the wall. You can get into the room via a manhole under the table. The guard has a large dish full of pellets on the table and a key on his belt.You try to reach for the keys. You're not allowed to do that.You try to reach for the pellets on the table. You're not allowed to do that.you try to do both in the moment when the guard is aiming and has his attention elsewhere. You're not allowed to do that.You slowly, slowly, slowly, shuffle your way back down the tunnel.You try going back to your cell to see if there's anything you missed. the exit is wide open, but you're still not allowed back in.You slowly, slowly, slowly, shuffle your way back down the tunnel.You go back to the room with the guard. You notice that he tips back in his chair every time he goes to take a shot. You click on the chair, hoping to send him tumbling backwards. Nothing happens.Enraged, you finally crack, and decide to use the walkthrough provided in-game. You slowly, slowly, slowly scroll through the randomly-generated shooter level.When you finally get the walkthrough! the answer was... to click on the guard's chair, knocking him over. You enter an entirely new realm of anger when you realize that you were supposed to click on the guard's chair, you just didn't click on the bottom of the front left leg. This is the only game I've played where you could be right, but still be wrong.That, and a lot of the artistic choices prevent the game from playing well as a point-and-click. Specifically, because none of the characters speak, there's no proper way to examine your environment besides looking at it. For example, in one scene, you have to dry some lichen on a lightbulb. However, the light was in a thick-looking glass housing with metal bands, nothing really indicated that it was hot. In any other P&CA, you could look at the light, and your character would say "It's hot." or something similar.Also, the game's main means of movement is horrible. The robot is SO SLOW! the game also doesn't include any sort of automatic movement when iteracting with the environment. If you drag an item out of your inventory and click it on something in the environment, what do you expect from a P&CA? for your character to either say "that won't work" or to walk over and do something with the item. In this game, you have to click on where you want to go, then watch the robot slowly waddle over, then take the item out of your inventory and use it. It seems like a minor gripe, but when you've played other P&CAs it gets so obnoxious, like a child who won't eat if his sandwich isn't cut at a precisely 62.5 degree angle.In short, this game doesn't want you to play good, it wants to look good.

content:
Posted: March 11
												Beautiful design, but also very poorly designed. While it looks wonderful, and is a brilliant idea there are too many issues once you get into the game. For example the saved file system is atrocious. Unlike normal steam games the files and most importantly the saved files are not stored in the steam folder but in your operating systems user folder. this is because it uses flash, and if you just happen to delete your browser history and wipe the cookies, believe it or not, your Machinarium saved files go too. Given the difficulty of the game, this in itself is a reason not to bother, but coupled with the ridiculous difficulty hike part way through, and a number of in game puzzles that are almost impossible and you can see why I didn't bother to play for more than a few hours before deleting this game forever.

												I haven't even played this game but it is a Flash game which means it handles poorly - this really should have been stated clearly when buying it.* If you use a clean up tool (e.g. CCleaner) then it will remove your save game if you don't tell it to exclude clearing Adobe Flash cache.* The game will only appear in a small area on your monitor taking up about 1200x800 - so if you have a 2560x1440 monitor like me then it will look ridiculous. number of helpful: 0 of 9 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												I really don't understand why there are so many positive reviews on this game...Machinarium is a classic point and click adventure. It has nice artwork and can be funny at times but that's about it.-The game is very linear compared to other games of the same genre (no backtracking), some people may like this but I found it removed most of the challenge associated with the genre.-The puzzles are very easy, might be appropriate for a very young kid but I can't picture anyone above 12 years old getting stuck anywhere, you are offered in-game hints and walkthrough wich I haven't considered using even once-The game is stupidly short (about 7 hours), if compared to other games of the same genre (I'm thinking of monkey island, deponia, grim fandango, etc.) the whole game has the lenght of about a single level of those titles I mentionedIf you ever see this game 75% off I would recommend buying it but not at full price. It won't live up to the expectations of any point-and-click adventure fans

content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												That awkward moment when a good friend gifts you a game that you're just not that into. I first played this a few years ago, shortly after it was released and had a wealth of critical acclaim surrounding it, but made the difficult and uncharacteristic decision to abandon it half way through as it was bugging me way too much to be bothered with it anymore. A combination of grindingly slow pacing, tedious, unsatisfying puzzles and downright depressing atmosphere put me off it way too quickly. But after receiving it as a birthday present, I felt I owed it to both the game and my friend to give it another shot and play it through to its entirety. Unfortunately, all that did was further reinforce my opinion that this game really isn't for me. Playing as a tiny, little robot, in a big, bad robot world, you'll point and click your way through sections of the city of Machinarium as you try to thwart the plans of a nasty gang of bullying, nogoodnik robots who've placed a bomb on the tower of your former place of residence... or workplace, it's hard to tell for sure. But apparently robots and their dwellings are pretty grim. Pretty much from top to bottom, everything feels dingy and bleak, like all hope is lost and everyone is now resigned to living a pitiful existence with no sign of ever getting better. Everything just felt so soul-crushingly oppressive and didn't make me want to stay a moment longer than I needed to, really not a good quality for a game. Normally dark tones in games don't bother me in the slightest, and if anything, really appeal to me. I felt right at home wandering the wastes of Fallout, or scavenging among the leftover detritus of humanity in S.T.A.L.K.E.R., but this just felt like too much even for me. At least Fallout has its dark humour laced throughout, and S.T.A.L.K.E.R. has its sense of mystery and vague suggestion that the outside world is a better place or people are building towards something better inside the disaster zone. But there's no such optimism here. It isn't even like it's a fictitious dystopia here, more like a way-too-close-to-reality feeling of dire finality and going through the motions. To their credit, the hand drawn art that makes up every part of the game is incredibly well done and feels like a real labour of love, like something much more personal that you don't get in other games. I just wish they had've chosen another direction for the aesthetics and made something less downbeat. Though I guess that's just going to come down to personal opinion more than anything. Aside from the opening introduction to the controls, there isn't a single line of text or dialogue throughout the game, with everything expressed through animated speech/thought bubbles or observing cues from the world and the robots that fill it. But, again, this only adds to tone. The subdued, mood music and low-rumbling barks and grunts of every other character further drills home how morbid everything feels. Yeah, in case you didn't already get it, I think this game is grim. There's something about Eastern European developers that makes them way too good at capturing those feelings in a game, with a sense that some studios are almost in a race to try and outgrim one another. Well, this feels like it could be their crowning achievement. Yet, even had the overall mood of the game been different, that still wouldn't have helped my issues with the slow crawl of so many parts of the game, or the fact that most of the puzzles felt like a chore to do, either because of the execution once you knew the solution, or finding the solution itself... and then executing it. I'm a fan of the studio's other works, Botanicula and the Samorost games, and I look forward to more titles along those lines if more point and click games are what they're sticking with. But unfortunately this is one I can't recommend above those and have no wish to ever visit again in future.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												I haven't played a lot of point-and-click games but I do know that Machinarium is overflowing with charm. The art style looks like it was sketched with colored pencils, the protagonist is a cute little robot that stores items in his belly, and the story is told through little cartoons in thought bubbles. The only reason I can't recommend this game is its difficulty. Perhaps it was intended for veteran point-and-click gamers but I found many of the puzzles to be difficult and confusing. Luckily, the developers decided to included hint for each level in the form of a cartoon bubble to help you understand what your primary goal is in each level. Unfortunately, most of the time I had no idea of how to get to that goal with whatever was placed before me in the level. The developers also included a walk-through for each level in the form of a book which you can unlock by playing a mini-game. The walk-through helps a lot but I found myself turning to its guidance for most of the levels (especially later in the game). It may have just been difficult for me but I don't want to continue playing a game where I constantly have to be taught how to play the game. That being said, you can tell that a lot of heart and soul went into this game. So if you're in to point-and-clicks, you might give this one a try.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												A decent puzzle game, aside from awkward mouse control (having to stand just so in order to frob the lever, having the game sometimes automate the extend/crouch mechanism, other times having to do so manually.)  Has a couple of action game puzzles - space invaders, and an annoying little room crawl shooting 33 little baddies, and a timed puzzle that really doesn't seem to give you enough time - I prefer my puzzle games in the Myst tradition of having no urgency aside from that driven by plot concerns, since it's a puzzle game and thus designed to be cryptic, and non violent.  Also, its a flash game, and thus much more limited in its interface than most games for sale these days.It was, at times, amusing and perhaps a little charming, but for maybe 5 hours of gameplay (significantly less if you're not missing clues along the way - most of my 3.3 hours of playtime was a wild goose chase trying to figure out which screen this particular oddity in my inventory was for.  (Very Monkey Island in that regard, but Monkey Island generally told you what the items were - it took me ages to figure out that the random piece of cloth I grabbed at one point was something called "flypaper", since I'd never heard of the stuff, or how it worked.)Did I have fun? yes.  Did I have $10 worth of fun?  No.  I picked it up during a holiday sale for 2.49, and that might be worthwhile.  No replay value to speak of - as you might expect, the puzzles don't change, and I didn't get invested in the characters enough to want to replay for the story, like I did with Myst and Portal (perhaps unfair to compare this game to those, though, given that they're abnormally good games.)

content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												Original Review:The art and music are nice, but it is SUPER easy for a point & click adventure/puzzle game. Unfortunately I can't recommend it based on this.Addition as of 12/5/2015:To elaborate, Machinarium does not play to the genre's strengths. It does not make many meaningful strides to get you to soak in its lustrous environments. The environments are... not quite lustrous either, which contributes to this disengagement. It needed to utilize the environments way more for it to be considered a really great point and click adventure game. Just see The Secret of Monkey Island: that game makes such excellent use of its environments, backgrounds, and setting, that it's no wonder why it's lauded as one of the BEST point and click adventure games ever made. Machinarium, on the other hand, is very amateur and did not make nearly as great an effort in immersing you within the game world.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Machinarium is a point-and-click adventure game that's mostly carried by its art style, because the actual gameplay is not very good. Unless the object you want to pick up is in the character's reach, there's no indication that the object is even something you can pick up. Not sure if it's because the game is made with Flash.The puzzles were mostly logical although some of them had a trial-and-error aspect. Hardest part of the puzzles was actually finding the items needed. There were a few quite challenging puzzles too. The game has an in-game walkthrough, but it requires you to play a mini-game every time you want to access it. Also the NPCs give some hints about the needed items when you "talk" to them.I found the story to be uninteresting even though it's told without words and is open for interpretation. Basically you're shown thought bubbles, which show a "flashback" of an event that happened. The story just didn't feel any fresh and it didn't make me care for the characters at all. Quite many people seem to find the plot great, which I find weird, because the plot is very generic. You can find similar plots in many other games as well as in many movies.I probably belong in the minority with my opinion about this game as I now think that it's overrated. It has a pretty nice art style and fairly good puzzles, but it still has somewhat clunky mechanics and a bland story. In my opinion Machinarium is just an average game and nothing more. I also managed to delete my save twice by using CCleaner, which cleared Flash cache.

number of helpful: 3 of 21 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												I've played much more of this game on a friend's tablet, so don't think this review is limited to the short playtime I have logged on Steam.  I'm severely neutral about this game, which is a shame given how enjoyable its atmoshpere is.  It is a pretty game, with an interesting touch of characterization on your little gizmo.  There are two reasons why I can't quite reccomend this game though, and while they don't make the game bad it definitely makes it worth less than the 10 USD price.First is a more personal peeve, it's made to immitate old-school point and click adventures in that there's a thread of logic that usually makes sense in the game world but doesn't if the immersion is broken.  That thread of how to progress can feel arbitrary, like the developers have contrived a reason why you can't just do a simple solution here, or why this device's switch is in a nigh-unaccesible alcove.  And that adventure game logic has always peeved me, but it's perfectly fine so long as you're immersed.Aaaaand that's the two of it: the immersion.  This game has a great soundtrack and needs it, because the gameplay is far from enough to pull (in my experience) the player in.  The tokenism and the obviously contrived puzzles are a big part of it, which encourages players to click around looking for what can and can't be used, but the other part is a bit more subtle.  Your character's competency changes, and that always pulls me out of a game.  Sometimes your character (Read: the game) will do something automatically that in a less-padded puzzle would have required you to hunt for an inventory item to do.  So occasionally I'm looking for what I believe is the last piece and then when I can't find it just rub my inventory against itself and give birth to progress.  That, or the gizmo guy can squeeze into or stretch to reach something that in a previous puzzle would not have been possible.Two faults, yes, and two major ones that the 10 USD price cannot afford to have.

number of helpful: 20 of 60 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2012
												Machinarium is an adventure game in the classic point & click style. A genre that by now only lives in the indie development scene. Whether that is a good or a bad thing is still up for debate.You play as a little lovable robot that seems to have been made out of mostly trash. As an entirely mute protagonist, as are every character in the game, mute that is, you experience the entirety of the storyline through little memory bubbles that pop every now and then to explain your connection to a particular item or individual. You may or may not understand them however.Gameplay is entirely point and click. You click on an object in the world to interact with it and on occasion pick it up. Items you collect can be used to interact with those same objects and occasionally can be combined with other collected items to form a new object. It is all very tried and true having been done this way for ages. Unfortunately Machinarium always keeps around some the failings of this genre. Many times you will find that you have to interact with a very specific part of a larger object with no discernible way to see which small place on the screen you have to click to make it work. The logic of the various puzzles, in true point and click fashion, marches to it's own drummer and if you approach the puzzles without being able to adopt this often bizarre method of thinking you will find your stumped quite often.Machinarium is quite a pretty game, despite being made entirely in flash it manages to produce a beautiful steampunkish environment that is very pleasing to the eye. Being made in flash however means that the occasional accidental right click can often ruin your day.All in all Machinarium is a fun little game if you're a fan of adventure point and clicks. It is however not a game that stands out in the genre or makes any attempt at even being playable for someone that is not a fan of the genre already.

number of helpful: 2 of 19 people (11%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												The first thing the game's tutorial tells you is that you can only click on things "in the robot's reach", but then keeps breaking that rule by randomly having the robot suddenly able to cartoonishly stretch out its arms and legs, and jump twice its own height. If this isn't poor sportsmanship on the designer's part, then maybe I just do not like point-and-click games anymore. The puzzles are mostly pretty neat, but there's enough extraneous visual and gameplay detail that it feels like you're being tricked into ignoring important clues. There are doors that you'll never open, but you can still yank on them. There are conspicuous items that scream out with potential that you can reach for but never pick up. Sometimes you'll pick up an item and it's simply not clear what it is; I went around clicking on everything in sight with what I thought was a corkscrew but turned out to be a strip of flypaper. Using the hint book is humiliating and needlessly complicated by an easy but dull minigame.There's lots of stupid minigame puzzles here, actually. It's okay to have a few, but after the sixth or seventh variation on peg-jumping or whatever, one realizes they're vastly inferior to environmental puzzles because they're disproportionately time-consuming for how little narrative importance they carry: for example, it is not compelling to spend ten minutes staring at an elevator keypad, even if the puzzle is an interesting one. And then finally, the big climax is a literal mini video game itself, on a tiny screen, that looks boring, has annoying music, and terrible controls.The story? You are a robot in a city populated entirely by robots. You begin the game after having been dismantled and thrown in a junkyard, and once you fix yourself you set out to get revenge, and, uh, save your girlfriend, I guess. I don't understand why "save your girlfriend" is still such a fixture even in indie games. And so often there's a inept, painful sincerity to it; Nintendo doesn't expect your heart to be in your throat when Bowser tosses Peach over his shoulder like a sack of potatoes, but the makers of Machinarium are hell bent on pushing this trite cliche to its fullest in the interest of giving you the ooie-gooies, and it comes off as lazy, not charming. Why are these robots gendered, anyway? Probably the same reason they still have human religions! Incidentally, that was my favorite part of the game. Cute, funny, clever, refreshingly inoffensive, and a good puzzle to boot. At least this review is ending on a positive note.

number of helpful: 9 of 35 people (26%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												Machinarium is a point-and-click adventure with beautiful, hand-drawn graphics. That's where the good stuff ends. The puzzles are convoluted and excessive; because hey, why do a puzzle once when you can do it four times? The character you control is painfully slow at moving around and it takes a good 10 or 20 seconds just to move from area to area. Every scene has annoying ambience that endlessly loops. I ended up turning the sound off  because I was so sick of the bloody noise. There are several points where you have to twist your mouse about awkwardly to do stuff; eg turning a wheel. Rather than just moving the wheel with the cursor, you have to circle around it twenty times. The worst point came when there was a puzzle that demanded that you flicked the mouse up and down really quickly. It took me twenty minutes to get the damn thing to work and I had to switch to a different mouse because the puzzle was so broken. The game is frustrating and tedious. I can understand why people would enjoy the story and interesting world it takes place in but the gameplay is more stressful than fun.

number of helpful: 2 of 19 people (11%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												I thought I reviewed this previously. Anyway, Machinarium has a unique style, but doesn't hold up greatly these days. The primary issue is the reliance on Flash, making the game unstable and buggy. Clearing Flash data will erase your save, but at least the game is short enough that it can be beat in one sitting, assuming it doesn't crash. Puzzles are mostly a hunt for objects that blend into the environment, sometimes involving trial and error. The long animation times became annoying at times, making backtracking obnoxious and save-deleting crashes just made me quit. Story pieces are told by animated sequences, but cannot be skipped. Some elements are done purely for charm, such as making the robot walk at half-speed when extended, but charming aspects shouldn't interfere with gameplay so much. Many puzzle elements are ambiguous, but items will never allow mistakes. The robot will just shake "no" with very few explanation animations in the game, so there seems to be 1 approach to everything.I guess the game is not too far from Kaptain Brawe, which I am playing now and then. I feel like that game is more charming and feels less obscured by muddy art, and isn't wasting my time with crashes and long animations. Still, this game is far from the value of $10, and it got on my nerves.

number of helpful: 1 of 17 people (6%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												I don't tend to like point and click games. Mostly because if the puzzles and controls aren't perfect then you can waste alot of time trying to find a solution that you already found. For example, an early puzzle invoules putting something on some train tracks. This was the very last step of the puzzle, and I spent maybe 5 minutes putting this thing on the tracks, trying to solve the puzzle, and having it fail. After many annoyed clicks I discovered that if you lower your mouse down to the other side of the tracks you can put it there. The problem is the click box for the wrong side of the tracks was so big, that you would assume that that is all you could do with it. Suffice it to say, I was very annoyed at this. I played through, and figured that was an one off event.In the very next screen I figure out the puzzle in a reasonable amount of time, but the very last step was bugged. As in I would click on the thing, and it wouldn't work. After maybe 10 minutes of cursing at it, I quit out of the game, and come back to it the next day. The exact same action I was trying to do before works the first time. It was just that the game wasn't reading my clicks correctly.On the very next screen, I get stuck again. This time because the puzzle wanted me to stand if a very exact spot for it to work. After reading a walk through, and finding out that I was doing the right thing, I tried different spots and quickly was able to continue.I play the game for about another 45 minutes until I run into the same bug of the game not reading my clicks. At this point I've had enough of the game. I really wanted to like this game, but the fact that the game could ruin the experience in many different ways put me off in a very bad way.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												I really wish there was a 'neutral' option for rating games, rather than just positive or negative.This game is beautiful to look at, and the melancholy, subdued tone of the artwork combined with the lovely music creates a wonderful overall aesthetic.Unfortunately, the gameplay itself soon became tedious and boring, and the lack of a story also meant there was little incentive for me to keep playing. Some of the of the puzzles are quite random and hard to figure out, and although the hint system is useful it's a pain to play the mini-game every time you want to take another look at the helpful diagrams.The world of Machinarium is unique and engaging, and if the game had been a few hours shorter then I would definitely recommend it. However, as it is I'm afraid I quickly came to find it dull and repetitive.

number of helpful: 5 of 27 people (19%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												I'm a sucker for some good point-and-click gamnes. But when it comes to this one, I can't recommend it.The art style makes everything extremely difficult to make out one item from another. Somethimes they hvae a VERY subtle glow, but even that isn't hepful. The game mechanics are interesting to say the least. You can only interact with things in your reach, and you can extend or retract your robots body to add height-specific puzzle solving. My complaints with the height changing are extremely lengthy. My main issue with it, is the walking speed. There's time sensitive puzzles you have to do early on in the game. And if you forget to retract your body (or raise it) you end up walking extremely slow. Lo and behold, you find yourself hobbling back to the original point of interest to restart the puzzle.The game does a terrible job of explaining anything to you, and the controls often feel clunky. Though the game is fun for a little bit, it finds itself repeated quite quickly.If point-and-click adventure games are your thing, I recommend anything but this game. It wore me out to the point where I don't even want to play any of the other games that do what this is trying to do, better.The normal price is $9.99 but is 65% off for $3.49 during the winter sale. I can't say it's a waste of money, because it's inexpensive and after an hour or so (give or take based on preference) pays for itself. If you can avoid buying it for full price but still want to pick it up, it's better to get it on sale, or wait for one. Otherwise, I don't feel it's really worth the trouble for $10 (or regional equal to USD)

												When there are so many much better modern adventure games there is no reason to buy junk like this, no matter how cheap the price.Puzzles are nosensical. Lots of random clicking everywhere on the screen. Problems with save games.

Posted: January 7, 2011
												The visual style of this point'n'click adventure game is fantastic and the art really makes exploring the world thoroughly enjoyable, but for me the music is the real gem in this game. Categorize it how you want (I choose ambient/downtempo) - the sound track is perfectly enjoyable all on its own and well worth the money you pay for the whole game.Little Robot is unceremoniously dumped out of his city and has to figure out how to get back inside and find his girlfriend. The puzzles are great, the hint system subtle yet useful, and some of the problems fiendishly difficult (without being impossible or incomprehensible).If you're the type of person who thinks completing a game is the only point, then stay away from this brain-teaser. (Using the walk-through it will take you a few hours to complete). But if you enjoy thinking, are happy to get stuck and leave the game alone for a night or two whilst you think what you could do, and prepared to use your grey matter, then buy this. Now.

Posted: May 11, 2014
												This is one of my favourite adventure games that I have played. The story is pretty simple yet well done and the combination of mechanics, art and music really makes this game enjoyable.I was initially attracted by the artwork when I played the demo on the developer's website but quickly was impressed by every other aspect of the game. If you're into point and click adventures, I'd definitely recommend this one.The only issue that I had (and it was a very big one) is that the save files were not working for me. I've heard complaints about this issue on the forums and such but basically you would save a game into a slot and when you open the game next time, the save file is gone. This prevented me from finishing the game for a long time and was very frustrating. A couple of times I tried to finish the game in a single play-through but that was not possible for me. Fortunately, the save files worked on my brand new computer so I'm thinking it's something to do with a few systems. I'm not sure.

Posted: January 9, 2014
												A throwback to classic adventure/puzzle games like King's Quest and Sam & Max. The good:-Beautiful Artwork-Incredible soundtrack-Item management -- the game automatically discards items when you've solved the related puzzle, so you never build a huge inventory of items that you never use again. (forcing you to wonder if you should)-Very clever puzzles-Tells a rich story with absolutely no dialog.-There are many funny moments.The bad:-It's too short! I beat it in 4 hours.-There's no replay value once you beat the game, unless you just want to go through the story again. Such is always the problem with adventure/puzzle games.The weird:-It's an Adobe Flash game wrapped up in a program.

Posted: November 27, 2010
												This masterpiece by Amanita Design is funny, complex, maddening, clever, and extremely well designed. As adventure games go there is some pixel hunting. More often than not you are clearly presented with a puzzle that seems unsolvable at first, but that is where the real joy in this game is found. Whether it's a new character or item you can use, or figuring out a 2 or 3 layer puzzle, each layer more difficult than the last.Take a second to admire the art. Never have I seen so much detail packed into a 2D environment. There's much life in this robotic and automated world. A tremendously beautiful and difficult adventure game. You will know a robot could love. Funny, quirky, smart, and genuine. Buy it!

Posted: February 23, 2011
												A beautiful adventure game by Czech developer Amanita, beautiful in concept, music and atmosphere among numerous other things.However, I must say that I hated the first hour of the game. Being a fan of the old adventure titles such as Monkey Island series, The Fate of Atlantis and Day of the Tentacle (mostly all the Scumm games), I found the logic behind Machinarium's puzzle a little bit incoherent.Puzzles aren't solved in the way you would thinkthey should. Instead they are solved mainly by the stuff you manage to pick up from around the game. Some items don't really seem to be a certain puzzle's solution but it just turns out that it is.Overall, Machinarium is a great and aspiring game that strives to be on par with Monkey Island or Day of the Tentacle, but it's the lack of experience on the developer's part that couldn't give it this small boost. I expect upcoming games by Amanita to conquer the adventure market!

Posted: July 12, 2012
EDIT: The text below was written before Steam Recommendations became Steam Reviews.Unforgettable adventure game. Machinarium is a flash-based, point and click game with great hand-made graphics and a stunning soundtrack composed by Tomáš Dvořák. There are many interesting, untypical puzzles to solve, some are quite hard, but you can always use "The Tome of Tips", as I like to call it, if you're stuck. It's available all the time, you just have to unlock it first by playing a mini-game. Machinarium is rather short, it takes about seven hours to finish it without using hints or about three hours if you play for the second time and know exactly what to do. Is it worth it? Absolutely. I would say that for this price you won't get a more charming game than Machinarium. I have good memories with this game. Reminds me a little of Stanisław Lem's book, "The Cyberiad". If you are still uncertain then try out the demo on the official website. No need to download any files!

Posted: February 5, 2011
												This is a quaint and short adventure game in which you control a little robot as he tries to uncover an evil scheme. This game takes a little getting used to at first, but once you familiarise yourself with the interface you will not find it too hard to play. One of the nicest features of this particular adventure game is the 'guide book'. If you become stuck, you can play a short minigame to access the guide book which will tell you exactly what to do. That might make it sound a little easy; but the thing is, while the book is open you cannot see the rest of the screen; and whenever you close the book, you must replay the minigame to reopen it. This game is definitely worth checking out, although at $20 it seems a little steep given how short it is.

Posted: May 5, 2016
 Machinarium So.. Machinarium.. This is really one of those games that allready has so many positive reviews that it might not need another one. But here it goes:Machinarium is set to a universe where there seems to be no humans. Instead there is machines building machines. As you can see from the screenshots posted on the store page of the game, it almost seems like it takes place in a junkyard, where the living machines often are built from scrap metal. Even tho these are machines and don't speak, they have character, and show emotions. Gameplay & Stroy:Machinarium follows the old and well known point and click game mechanic. It is a story driven adventure/puzzle game, that has a rather serious story, but manages to add humor to it on several places.The story captured me from the very first moment that i started playing this. I don't want to ruin the story for those who haven't played this yet, so im not going to cover any part of the story in this review.As mention above, the characters in Machinarium don't speak, but they show thinking boubles above their head and make noises (an alternative way to give the player hints about what they need to do next). This method, in my opinion works very well. Puzzles: I have played many puzzle games and i have to say that for me, this was kind of perfect in terms of difficulty. Many puzzle games tend to become to confusing when they try to make it a big and challenging game. Like having a big area with lots and lots of things to interact with, without a single clue on what to do next. Machinarium manages to give you a lot of different options on what to interact with, but at the same time you get enough hints on what your goal is that you for example knows that you have to do someting with this item, just not what. Level design:The levels in Machinarium are great actually. There is a lot of variations and different enviroments through out the game. They also made the levels in a way that you get a feeling of a big living world even outside of the playable areas. You still have to remember that this is a sideview game with limited possibilities of movement. Still, there is depth in the levels, so you can for example walk away and towards the camera. Nostalgia:For me these kinds of games gives me some nostalgia from the time around 2001-2006 when i used to play games like these on flash sites all the time. There is something "calming" about sitting there without any stress, and figuring out these sorts of games. Of course Machinarium is more polished, longer and better than most free flash games out there.Bugs & Crashes:So far in my review, i've only said positive things about Machinarium. But as many other games before it, Machinarium suffers when it comes to bugs and crashes. I experienced several times during my playthrough that the games just froze with a black screen. I still could hear the music but i had to close it through task manager and restart it to keep playing. I also experienced that the game just closed for no apparent reason, and sometimes while playing and i clicked on something, nothing happened in-game. But since this is a very small game in terms of size, and that it practically doesn't require anything to run, it took me seconds to restart and be back in it. Conclusion:Machinarium is a great game, really. If you like story driven puzzle games i would recommend you to get this.

Posted: July 12, 2015
												Machinarium is a Point&Click with a brilliant and beautiful universe. Sounds and musics are made with metallic noises. There’s a lot of humor too. The story is about a world of robots; we control a small robot which was thrown to the dump and is going to return in town to repair the insult which was made for it. Dialogues and flashbacks are made in drawn bubbles.The difficulty is more present than in Botanicula for several reasons: at first, objects to be collected are facing in the background, so they are not easily locatable at first glance and force us to look well everywhere.Secondly, the robot has the capacity to change its size; what makes that there are actions which we can make only for a certain height and not for an other one.Finally, the objects which we collect can sometimes merge between them to form only one.The whole allowing to have riddles a little more complex, increasing the interest and the length of the game.However, even by being blocked, no need to fetch the soluce on Google. The game integrates itself the solutions of 2 manners: in every area, it is possible to consult a clue, which just gives the main action to realize at one time or another to finish the area. But it is also possible to consult the guide of solutions (which is a comic strip showing step by step what to do to achieve the level), if you manage to play with success to a short shooting game.Indeed, numerous short games punctuate Machinarium: several puzzles, riddles and games like Space Invaders.In conclusion, a very good Point&Click game, with a well thought universe and a good level of difficulty!

Posted: June 19, 2016
												Your usual adventure game but with a catch. There's no text in the whole game, relying mostly on visuals to tell its basic story and hint what do do next. The latter is the true challenge of the game, which is not new in this genre, but several puzzles will make you go in circles. Fortunately you have a minigame that if beated, it will give you the full playthrough of the screen you're in, so you can work a little extra to get the solution rather just googling it.The game works in flash and that's probably its main problem. The game runs well, but some inputs can be rough specially as the character has a very limited area to interact with. There's also some puzzles that might feel the game becomes either bugged or unresponsive, so better double check before making assumptions.If you figure out all its puzzles Machinarium is actually pretty short. But due how vague the game is hinting the next step as well the limited interaction range will force you into, is not a game that you can beat by just clicking everything until the character walks into it.

Posted: June 20, 2016
												Machinarium is a cute and funny game about a robot who have had enough of bullying and corrupt systems. The main robot of the game finds itself in a landfill and after figuring out how to assemble itself begins its quest of getting back home and stopping the evildoers that has been supressing it for so long.The game features a lot of minigames and puzzles, most of which are classic logic question of geometrical type but also some new and clever ideas that are really challenging. The storyline is a bit wierd and since none of the characters really say anything, it's hard to realize where you should go after you've solved a part of the puzzle. The developers have made a smart solution to this by implementing a "tips and tricks"-help manual that you can only access after you have played a short bit of simple sidescroller.I've only had the opportunity to play it once, and since it only took me roughly five hours (even with getting stuck and trying many different paths time and again) I do not feel like this is a game that I want to own. Even though there is the option to solve some things in different order, it is a very linear game with few things that are out of the main quest.Overall I think that Machinarium is a really cute game, a nice challenge for anyone that are new to puzzle solvers or really like playing a lot of them and the design in it is really wonderful.85% is my rating

												Nothing screams masterpiece more than a solid point-and-click post-apocalyptic adventure. Played completely through remarkably sketched illustrations, the game's lack of text is a testament to its outstanding storytelling and well-crafted puzzles. And the package is only sweetened by its utterly captivating soundtrack.

Posted: June 26, 2015
												Machinarium is a beautiful point and click puzzle with lovely and very original hand-drawn graphics and a nicely-told classical story. The music and sound are perfect for this game. Some of the puzzles are easy while others will make you go back and forth to look for items or actions you could have forgotten. The game runs very smoothly and as expected with this kind of game, the pace is rather slow and calm and the game is rather short (but not too short).Amanita hasn't fully solved a very annoying issue: sometimes you cannot resume a saved game and the main menu shows only the "Play new game" option. They provide a solution where you can start from pre-saved files with the basic progression of each level and continue your adventure from there, but this falut is honestly very frustrating.The game is beautiful. If you don't mind searching the official page for those pre-saved files if you're unlucky, I recommend you to give it a go.

Posted: September 26, 2015
												Hands down my favorite game soundtrack of all time. Thomas Dvorak has created a music masterpiece to accompany this gorgeous game about a little robot trying to save his city and get his girl robot. Some of the puzzles can get tedious, but the adventure game aspect is beautiful. One of the best hidden gems on Steam.

Posted: September 26, 2015
												Machinarium tells the unconventional story of a charming little robot living in an enigmatic automaton world. Beautiful yet monochromatic hand-drawn environments are filled with appreciable minute details, all rendered in a very unique style. Mostly logical and diverse puzzles aided by clever subtle guidance make the player feel smart and rarely at a loss for progression.This moderately short game is nonetheless of a very satisfying length. It features a solid and enjoyable soundtrack that perfectly accompanies every scene. The game's adroit presentation even manages to make players understand characters' needs and emotions flawlessly without necessitating a single line of dialogue, adding to the charismatic otherworldliness.I've been wanting to play this game since its release but somehow managed to procrastinate over half a decade before finally indulging. As a result, its Flash engine now shows its age and limitations, and the game's medium resolution assets do not use full screen (black borders fill all four sides). The clunky inventory interface doesn't work as well as it should but at least nothing feels broken.Some mildly repetitive sections could have been improved, and despite all its prowesses the game has no truly impressive wow factor (nor any major flaw). A consistently competent and enjoyable experience throughout should please most adventure fans.

Posted: September 14, 2015
												A wonderful point-and-click walkaround game.  The art and music are attractive and atmospheric.   I had to do very minimal clue-googling, and in both cases I felt sure I wouldn't have solved the puzzle on my own.  My only complaint is that two of the minigames are reflex-based (a Pacman-like robot-killing game and a Space Invaders game) and they don't fit the atmosphere or style of the rest of the game.   Furthermore, the robot-killing game doesn't allow keyboard controls: it's mouse-only.   But that's a nitpick.  Overall the puzzles are varied and fun and I felt a real sense of achievement when I figured each one out.

I'm not a parent so I can't say for certain that it's kid friendly but there's no violence in it and it's just a sweet love story.

Posted: December 18, 2010
												This little flash based game, be it the futuristic music or the beautiful graphics, is a true work of art.  Also there are no long and annoying dialogues which usually can turn an adventure game into a frustrating event;  instead of verbal dialogues all forms of communication are graphical.  Plus, for those who get stuck, the game has a built in illustrated walkthrough for each level, which can be unlocked by playng a short and simple mini-game. The only downside, imo, is that some of the puzzles can be solved only through pure luck and guessing, and not logic, but that is where the built in walkthrough comes to the rescue.  All in all this is a gem of a game that every collector should have in their archive, especially those who want to give their support to independant game makers.

Posted: December 21, 2014
												Machinarium is a modern adventure game. Which means that it is short, with easy puzzles. However, it has a cute protagonist, and the puzzles are interesting. Machinarium is also a good transitional piece; if you like the casual hidden-object adventure games but find the traditional point-and-clicks to be too frustratingly hard, Machinarium may be a happy medium for you.Contrariwise, if you are a fan of classic point-and-click adventure games, you may find this one to be breezy and wonder what the fuss is about.

Posted: January 30, 2015
												This game is ♥♥♥♥ing beautiful. It has very addictive puzzle-solving mechanics and it has a silent yet artful story that can be interpreted differently by different people. It's a point and click game, and I usually don't like those, but this game had such a uniquely, slightly creepy yet somehow cheerful atmosphere.

Posted: January 13, 2015
												Machinarium is fantastic. The only bad thing I can think of is there is no sequel and the second game from Amanita just did not have the same anthropomorphic charm as Machinarium.This is a living work of art and is a must-play in my opinion.

Posted: January 11, 2015
												Machinarium is an adventure game with a more than charming art style. It has got its fair share of challenging puzzles but for the experienced fan of adventure games should get through those as well. The game has a simple, yet charming storyline and a hand full of quirky, but lovable charakters. Most interesting point of this game is, that it needs absolutely no dialogue and still anyone should be able to understand it. In the end I think, the sellingpoint of this game is the interesting art style. If you are the type of gamer who enjoys that kind of thing, this game is a must have. If you expect another monkey island or broken sword, I wouldn't recommend it.

Posted: January 27, 2015
												One of my ABSOLUTE favorite games of all time! Point and Click games are my favorite and this game was both challenging and amazingly fun at the same time. The multiple dimensions of the game really added to my overall experience and left me wanting to continue on forever! I loved the feature where you collected items and could combine them to create new tools to utilize in the game. The story was undeniably adorable, extremely creative, and original. I enjoyed every moment of this game and would recommend it to ALL! The built in "one hint" feature was awesome and provided me with just the right amount of support to get me unstuck at the frustrational level, yet still leave me to figure out the main chunk of the puzzle. The character development, crazy puzzles, and phenomenal graphics grabbed my attention, stretched my thinking, and had me laughing at the unbelievable attention to detail and added humor all at the same time. This game is truly fun and engaging by every definition under the sun.

I still listen to the soundtrack. Also, the story still managed to touch my heart despite not using words to do so. Visual narratives, in my opinion, always have the greatest impact when done right. I look forward to playing Botanicula now :)

Posted: September 26, 2015
												Machinarium tells the unconventional story of a charming little robot living in an enigmatic automaton world. Beautiful yet monochromatic hand-drawn environments are filled with appreciable minute details, all rendered in a very unique style. Mostly logical and diverse puzzles aided by clever subtle guidance make the player feel smart and rarely at a loss for progression.This moderately short game is nonetheless of a very satisfying length. It features a solid and enjoyable soundtrack that perfectly accompanies every scene. The game's adroit presentation even manages to make players understand characters' needs and emotions flawlessly without necessitating a single line of dialogue, adding to the charismatic otherworldliness.I've been wanting to play this game since its release but somehow managed to procrastinate over half a decade before finally indulging. As a result, its Flash engine now shows its age and limitations, and the game's medium resolution assets do not use full screen (black borders fill all four sides). The clunky inventory interface doesn't work as well as it should but at least nothing feels broken.Some mildly repetitive sections could have been improved, and despite all its prowesses the game has no truly impressive wow factor (nor any major flaw). A consistently competent and enjoyable experience throughout should please most adventure fans.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												Machinarium is a fun little game. It's full of puzzles and has a really interesting little world of robots to explore. It can be pretty easy to get lost sometimes though because sometimes your objectives aren't clear. You also have to keep a sharp eye out because some things can be missed pretty easily. There's a good bit of running around back and forth when you're tying to figure things out, but if you get truly stuck the game actually has a walkthrough built inside of it. If you like puzzles and cute robots Machinarium is worth a try. The art is pretty and has a nice sketchy look to it. Plus some of the little robot's reminiscing is   pretty funny. If you liked Botanicula it's made by the same guys so you'll probably like it.

Posted: July 21, 2012
												The game has overall cute if - at some time - repetitive animations (when letting the main charater just sitting there) or having him perform a task. Also remarkable is the hand-drawn scenary at every single screen (there're so much details drawn to match the ambiance).That's combined with increasing difficulty at small technical and logical riddles (say: minigames) all along the way to the goal where it started to go all wrong - that much for revealing the background story.Most of the time you'll have to complete a string of actions before getting to the next screen and more often to solve some brain-teasers to proceed.The real task is mostly to understand what's the goal of the minigame before accomplishing it since there're only abstract hints to the task: one for free by clicking the bulb following an animated film to get  the global picture (rather than having the whole solution picture-wise after sucessfully shooting from a key at lots of moving spiders hanging from a thread).

Posted: April 20, 2012
												If you love puzzle games, or point and click. This is the perfect game for you.This game is a very well put together puzzle game mixed with Point and click.The artstyle is fantastic, the puzzles are equally dificult. Some are easy to figure out, while others leave you scratching your head, wondering what to do. The story in this game is very clear, even though not a single word is spoken throughout the entire game. It's cheap, and may only grant you one or maybe two playthroughs, but i would definitely recommed this game.The music is another thing about the game that is great. You have the option to turn it off, but throughout my nearly 3 hour playthrough of the game, i didn't. I never found it to be annoying or anything like that.The interface is great, very simplistic and minimalistic, but very easy to navigate.It gives you a very easy to follow on how to play the game and use the games different mechanics.I can only recommend this game. Do check it out!

												A point and click adventure with a bit of a twist, you can only operate / pick up items that are within your reach, and there isn't anything that shows you you can use it unless your within reach of it.It's quite short but it makes up for the fact by being pretty difficult, and the story is well told.

Posted: December 3, 2010
												Machinarium is a beautifully done puzzle adventure. Not as long as games like Myst, but the journey is a wonderful experience full of unusual thinking and robotic conundrums. The characters are cute, and well made, as well as full of personality which is rare for a puzzle game. The presence of a hint for each area is helpful for those who get stuck, and if you really want a solution you can work through a mini-game, moving a key through a side-scrolling maze while avoiding the spiders (or shooting them) and not touching the walls or bricks, until you find the keyhole at the end, which unlocks the walkthrough book and shows you a page for the area you're in with a step by step picture guide of what needs to be done. It thoughtfully avoids any spoilers, and has a few surprises for those who explore possibilities aside from those needed to directly progress. A good game, with fun and cute characters, a fantastic style, plenty to see, and a great ending. It's worth the price.

Posted: November 2, 2011
												You're a robot, what else must be said? the art in this game is truly amazing, the world has a weird emptiness about it, and a feel of neglect for the whole city, but still manages to be beautiful, and ever so inviting in its rusted out corridors. As for the story, you must rescue your Girl Friend from the kitchen, yes the kitchen. As she was kid napped and taken away and forced to cook for your enemies, as there is no talking in this game, every thought and emotion is displayed in a very pretty little thought bubbles, and the emotion of the protagonist is displayed just right. My last statement, are the puzzles some of these puzzles are push overs, others will take a wile, and might even require you to get the answer in this handy little answer book that is always available to you, so your not stuck on the same puzzle for 10 days strait ripping out your hair. Add all this up, and you got a nice little puzzle game about love and robots, a good buy.

Posted: June 4, 2015
												Machinarium, a very stylized puzzle game made by Amanita Design. It starts off with a robot named Josef landing in a junkyard who eventually makes his way back home, after a brief encounter with some criminal robots the story slowly unfolds to what Josef must do. The design of this robot world is very stylized with its design and characters, the music reminds me of the classic Spyro the Dragon series as both of their music have a very other worldy quality. Gameplay wise it's a real challenge, the puzzle can sometimes be hard to get through that I ended up looking for a walkthrough to solve some of them lol But there are some fun little mini games here and there so it's not always that frustrating. This is definantly worth a buy for those of you that want to face a real challenging puzzle game.

Posted: February 23, 2011
												A beautiful adventure game by Czech developer Amanita, beautiful in concept, music and atmosphere among numerous other things.However, I must say that I hated the first hour of the game. Being a fan of the old adventure titles such as Monkey Island series, The Fate of Atlantis and Day of the Tentacle (mostly all the Scumm games), I found the logic behind Machinarium's puzzle a little bit incoherent.Puzzles aren't solved in the way you would thinkthey should. Instead they are solved mainly by the stuff you manage to pick up from around the game. Some items don't really seem to be a certain puzzle's solution but it just turns out that it is.Overall, Machinarium is a great and aspiring game that strives to be on par with Monkey Island or Day of the Tentacle, but it's the lack of experience on the developer's part that couldn't give it this small boost. I expect upcoming games by Amanita to conquer the adventure market!

Posted: February 11, 2014
												Machinarium is a Flash based point and click adventure game that is unique in its execution.  Each area has readily accessable hint and a full walkthrough of the area at the cost of playing a somewhat tedious mini-game to keep you from looking at it unless you're really stuck.  The robot you control can be stretched shorter or taller with a mouse drag which gives you the ability to reach areas you couldn't without it and adds complexity to many of the game's puzzles.  Most of the puzzles are pretty simple and produce, at most, a moderate challenge.The real appeal of this game though is its art.  Almost everything is made of metal and the way it's drawn and painted gives the abstract looking structures a touch of realism that shows each ones age through how rusted or weathered it looks.  The ambient music helps to set the darkish tone of the game with mechanical and lo-fi sounds. While I'm on the topic of tone despite the dark atmosphere, the character you play as, and many of the ones you meet, are quite peppy and charming which gives an interesting contrast that made me feel as if the robots were living it a different paradigm.It might just be nostalgia, but I miss adventure games, and I really feel the medium still holds up today; at least on PC's.

Posted: February 10, 2014
												Yeah!:Gorgous hand drawn point and click adventure set in a robot world. Length is pretty good as well.Meh!: Some puzzles are annoying(Looking at you King's brain action mini game) or difficult(Bomb).Bleh!: The fact that your character can only interact(or know its clickable) with objects with in reach of its arms is annoying. This has you basically moving the chacter around the screen at his snail pace to make sure you have everything. Wish there was ability to skip screen transition animations to speed things up.Verdict: A gorgous point and click adventure that is just right in difficulty most of the time. A few of the mini-game puzzles do annoy and seem out of place in the genre but can be overlooked in the overall picture. Not worth full price, but was worth it via the humble bundle obtained in.***/5

Posted: April 21, 2014
												Excellent, Beautiful and original adventure set in the old-school point & click style. The comical animations, emotive personalities of the characters through imagery alone, and incredible backdrops all hand-drawn to extremely high quality finish combined with a humorous and engaging storyline clearly outline the level of attention to detail and an affectionate amount of dedication from developers.Machinarium is a great title for those who seek a more cerebral, perhaps slower-paced gameplay than many of the frustrating arcade games around. The puzzles are clearly described and visible clues help to keep on the right track, so there's little chance of being utterly 'stuck'. Even in such situations, there is a buiilt-in diagramatic walkthrough guide for every puzzle that requires a fun little mini-game to view.At such a bargain price, you can't really go wrong with this game. I wholeheartedly recommend Machinarium to any fans of puzzles/adventure games or just gamers in general who seek something a little different...

												This is one of my favourite adventure games that I have played. The story is pretty simple yet well done and the combination of mechanics, art and music really makes this game enjoyable.I was initially attracted by the artwork when I played the demo on the developer's website but quickly was impressed by every other aspect of the game. If you're into point and click adventures, I'd definitely recommend this one.The only issue that I had (and it was a very big one) is that the save files were not working for me. I've heard complaints about this issue on the forums and such but basically you would save a game into a slot and when you open the game next time, the save file is gone. This prevented me from finishing the game for a long time and was very frustrating. A couple of times I tried to finish the game in a single play-through but that was not possible for me. Fortunately, the save files worked on my brand new computer so I'm thinking it's something to do with a few systems. I'm not sure.

Posted: December 3, 2010
												Machinarium is a beautifully done puzzle adventure. Not as long as games like Myst, but the journey is a wonderful experience full of unusual thinking and robotic conundrums. The characters are cute, and well made, as well as full of personality which is rare for a puzzle game. The presence of a hint for each area is helpful for those who get stuck, and if you really want a solution you can work through a mini-game, moving a key through a side-scrolling maze while avoiding the spiders (or shooting them) and not touching the walls or bricks, until you find the keyhole at the end, which unlocks the walkthrough book and shows you a page for the area you're in with a step by step picture guide of what needs to be done. It thoughtfully avoids any spoilers, and has a few surprises for those who explore possibilities aside from those needed to directly progress. A good game, with fun and cute characters, a fantastic style, plenty to see, and a great ending. It's worth the price.

Posted: December 22, 2013
												6/10 point-and-click. Visually this thing is killer and a ton of fun to experience. The concept is just very well thought out and the puzzles are clever and frankly some of the smartest I've ever played. Mechanically, this game is just awful at times which is silly since it's a mechanical world (face-palm for dumb pun). It's a flash port so don't expect it to be super well optimized for any system. The thing that just cranked my gears the wrong way was that I would click to go somewhere and realize I had left the robot's body elongated or shortened which makes him travel at half the pace. You can't redirect him back mid-travel, as far as I know you can't speed up the game, and you can't readjust him to normal height while he's walking either making for a lot of headbanging on my desk waiting for the stupid robot to get to the place he needed to go. Other than that, it has a killer aesthetic and a fun dialogue free story which is just fantastic and you should definitely give this game a try if you're at all into these kind of adventures. The docked points were for the time wasting oversights and not for the actual puzzles themselves which were easily some of the best I've ever seen in any game.

Posted: February 21, 2014
												If you have played computer games for longer than the past decade (or if you have a taste for the classics) then you have played one or more of those old point-and-click adventure games, like those of old-school Lucasarts fame. Machinarium really brings you back to that time, when games did not have to be about leveling-up, taking the shot, making that jump, or fighting your way to the next checkpoint just in case that one annoying enemy takes away your last few hit points. Machinarium is a hallmark of this old-fashioned game style. In a time when few studios focus on this type of game, it is amazing to see an indie game with this level of artistic development. Every screen is unbelievably beautiful and breathtaking. The simple, hand-drawn characters have depth and personality that even the greatest mo-capped, celebrity-voiced charicatures cannot match. The puzzles are just right: not too easy, not too hard. Most of the time, the solution will come to you and you will think, "Why did I not think of that before?" THAT is what makes a great point-and-click adventure, and Machinarium is definitely a great game.

												Machinarium is an excellent point-and-click adventure. Posted: June 25, 2014
												So pretty. Painterly, cartoonish images that embody the charm and decay of the environment and characters, with a fantastic, eminently listenable soundtrack. The puzzles are sufficiently challenging, even bewildering at times, but if you've played a point-and-click adventure, you know what you're in for; there is a hint system in place, integrated beautifully and playfully. Plot and backstory are fed to you with a dropper, via daydreams of the cute little robot protagonist. In sum, it's handcrafted in the best sense, imperfections included: fun, adorable, clever, and engaging. And seriously, get the soundtrack.

Posted: June 22, 2014
												An imaginative adventure with the atmosphere and charm that can only come from an Amanita Design game, Machinarium puts you in the rusty metal body of a thoughtful robot. The player quickly becomes enraptured by the unique sound design, pantomiming characters, and gorgeous backgrounds along their journey. If you're looking for an immersive world to lose yourself in for a few hour and are not afraid to challenge your thinking skills every now and again, I wholeheartedly recommend Machinarium.

Posted: May 5, 2016
 Machinarium So.. Machinarium.. This is really one of those games that allready has so many positive reviews that it might not need another one. But here it goes:Machinarium is set to a universe where there seems to be no humans. Instead there is machines building machines. As you can see from the screenshots posted on the store page of the game, it almost seems like it takes place in a junkyard, where the living machines often are built from scrap metal. Even tho these are machines and don't speak, they have character, and show emotions. Gameplay & Stroy:Machinarium follows the old and well known point and click game mechanic. It is a story driven adventure/puzzle game, that has a rather serious story, but manages to add humor to it on several places.The story captured me from the very first moment that i started playing this. I don't want to ruin the story for those who haven't played this yet, so im not going to cover any part of the story in this review.As mention above, the characters in Machinarium don't speak, but they show thinking boubles above their head and make noises (an alternative way to give the player hints about what they need to do next). This method, in my opinion works very well. Puzzles: I have played many puzzle games and i have to say that for me, this was kind of perfect in terms of difficulty. Many puzzle games tend to become to confusing when they try to make it a big and challenging game. Like having a big area with lots and lots of things to interact with, without a single clue on what to do next. Machinarium manages to give you a lot of different options on what to interact with, but at the same time you get enough hints on what your goal is that you for example knows that you have to do someting with this item, just not what. Level design:The levels in Machinarium are great actually. There is a lot of variations and different enviroments through out the game. They also made the levels in a way that you get a feeling of a big living world even outside of the playable areas. You still have to remember that this is a sideview game with limited possibilities of movement. Still, there is depth in the levels, so you can for example walk away and towards the camera. Nostalgia:For me these kinds of games gives me some nostalgia from the time around 2001-2006 when i used to play games like these on flash sites all the time. There is something "calming" about sitting there without any stress, and figuring out these sorts of games. Of course Machinarium is more polished, longer and better than most free flash games out there.Bugs & Crashes:So far in my review, i've only said positive things about Machinarium. But as many other games before it, Machinarium suffers when it comes to bugs and crashes. I experienced several times during my playthrough that the games just froze with a black screen. I still could hear the music but i had to close it through task manager and restart it to keep playing. I also experienced that the game just closed for no apparent reason, and sometimes while playing and i clicked on something, nothing happened in-game. But since this is a very small game in terms of size, and that it practically doesn't require anything to run, it took me seconds to restart and be back in it. Conclusion:Machinarium is a great game, really. If you like story driven puzzle games i would recommend you to get this.

Posted: December 1, 2014
												This game has so much to offer, if you're interested in this game: its definitely worth buying. I am not normally into Point & Click or Adventure style games, but this one really is a cut above the rest. The art and style of the game is really interesting and unique. It also doesnt try to be too obvious with all of the objects and clues, but it does have them. Its style and the world created by the visuals really gives the game some depth and character. The areas are varied and unique, but still remaining cohesive. My only possible complaint with art & visuals is that I wish it would fully scale & stretch up to 1080P, but with the way the game is designed and with the way the game's art is made, I understand and accept why it doesnt.The music is very good. It fits the areas in the game very well and gives it so much personality. All of the tracks are long enough and are composed in a way that wont become grating on your nerves, even if you get stuck or stumped by a puzzle for a very long time.  one of my favorite soundtracks I've heard recently.The puzzles are all well designed, and they tend to be fair and dont fall into the trope of being needlessly obtuse in the illusion of being "challenging." The difficulty progression of the puzzles is fairly gradual and it tries really hard to teach the player its style and how you should be approaching each puzzle as you go. Only a few of them really took me a while to figure out and even if you get stuck: theres in-game hints and when you are 100% stumped: it has an unlockable walkthrough (you have to do a mini side-scrolling shooter to open it up) and the walkthrough doesnt completely spoil the puzzles.
