Posted: July 4, 2016
Do robots dream of electric sheep?City robots Mashinarium, smelling of oil and covered with rust, live the life of a giant mechanism. You would never think that the same vending machine for batteries is also a robot! Originally posted by Jakub Dvorsky: - It happened on a distant and forgotten planet, where people used to send the garbage that they were producing old machines, mechanisms, computers, etc. This mechanical scrap was formed a few simple robots. Some time later they built other, more advanced robots, and then — settlement. Thus was created the city of Machinarium.  You play as a robot named Josef, Yes, our hero has a name, though it is not mentioned. You mistakenly throw away to the city dump, your girlfriend is kidnapped by the bandit and all around town is in danger! And who do you need to solve these problems? Of course You. Maybe You look funny, but full of resoluteness and courage.And so begins your exciting journey in the city of rusted steel, constantly working mechanisms and sleepless, the most diverse and unusual residents.Machinarium - a game of Czech developer Amanita Design company. Was created by the efforts of only 7 people and was sponsored by savings of developers. Guys, only 7 developers! And the project turned out just beautiful! Won many awards and entered the top 10 of "Best games of 2009" and is a game created in Adobe flash. Unlike stamped new games, before, tried to make something different, unique and memorable. In the game everything is fine. Great atmosphere, which is felt not only in the image created manually, but in a beautiful soundtrack. Each composition, each location gives a feeling of positivity and a sense of independent life of the city. Unusual for the time mechanics, which is expressed in the interaction of objects in the vicinity of the character, the change in the growth of Joseph and a complete lack of dialogue. The soundtrack deserves special mention. To listen to it forever. It is so beautiful that takes your mind straight to Machinarium, and your imagination just explodes. It also blends perfectly with real life. Listen to the song "The Bottom" or "Mr. Handagote" and watch the bustling city, just great.Puzzles also did not disappoint. They are funny, interesting and sometimes challenging. Will have to break your head a little bit, but it's worth it. Of course, the developers have simplified the game and after the passage of a small scrolling shooter, you can spy hints at this level. But I assure you, to do everything yourself - a lot of fun. Go back to the game and to pass it on a new, never get bored. She always looks fresh and breathtaking. I replayed it for the umpteenth time since its release and purchase the disc, and it is October 2009. 7 years, the game is not removed from my computer.Well, go ahead! Who knows what the outcome of Your little adventure?The game is definitely worth the money. And I hope, one day, will be its continuation.OVER9000 small Josefov out of 10.

Posted: January 7, 2011
												The visual style of this point'n'click adventure game is fantastic and the art really makes exploring the world thoroughly enjoyable, but for me the music is the real gem in this game. Categorize it how you want (I choose ambient/downtempo) - the sound track is perfectly enjoyable all on its own and well worth the money you pay for the whole game.Little Robot is unceremoniously dumped out of his city and has to figure out how to get back inside and find his girlfriend. The puzzles are great, the hint system subtle yet useful, and some of the problems fiendishly difficult (without being impossible or incomprehensible).If you're the type of person who thinks completing a game is the only point, then stay away from this brain-teaser. (Using the walk-through it will take you a few hours to complete). But if you enjoy thinking, are happy to get stuck and leave the game alone for a night or two whilst you think what you could do, and prepared to use your grey matter, then buy this. Now.

												This is easily one of the best puzzle games ever made, and definitely my favorite for this category. If you're looking for a tough puzzle game that has both incredibly art, and beautiful music, then this is the game for you. This point and click puzzle game will get you to think, and even though at times you may feel frustrated, the game puts a help book (mini-game included to unlock it) to help you on your journey if need be.I'd highly recommend anybody to buy this. Even when it's not on sale, it's still very affordable to buy. Do not forget to grab the soundtrack with it however, because it's definitely something you won't want to miss out on after playing through it. I nominate this game for the Test of Time award, because even though I've played this game over 5 times, I still have a lot of fun. I never fully remember how to do the puzzles, which keeps the game fresh everytime I play it, and even if I can speed through some of them, the cute story, incredibly visuals, and music just keep me going.10/10

Posted: November 27, 2016
												Cute, funny, and with a unique art style.In many games of this genre, you can get stuck because you didn't think of doing a totally unpredictable and illogical action. You then get frustrated and either give up or google for the solution. This game is not frustrating like that. It is designed in a way where the visuals give you subtle hints, an I never felt like "how could I possibly have known that?!?".Machinarium also has an in-game hint system, where you can get more hints and not the solution outright.From all the point-and-click games I've played, I give this game my highest recommendation.Don't leave this for too long in your backlog!

Posted: December 27, 2011
												Greastest game ever made. Soundtrack is beautiful. Art is stunning. The depth in this game is impalpable, but so simplistic at the same time. This game will give you a sense of how vast our world is, what is to come and how much we as humans don't know. The characters speak so loud and true, yet the world of Machinarium has no vernacular at all. Once you play this game, you are egulfed into a world of wondrous glee then petrified with a horrid layer of truthful saddness. Machinarium is a must play.10/10

Posted: June 12, 2014
												This is the best point and click adventure game I have ever played. It took me about 23-24 hours to complete. The puzzles are very interesting and challenging and I like a good challenge. The artwork is amazing and the gameplay is loads of fun. If you do ever get stuck, there is a pretty good hint system but I wouldn't rely on it, it's so much more satisfying to actually figure the puzzles out yourself. I could play this game forever without getting bored so it did not matter how long it took me to complete a puzzle. I highly recommend this game! ^_^

Posted: April 21
												Machinarium is lots of fun and highly enjoyable. I love the art style and the puzzles. If you get stuck, there's a book of hints to help you out. The hints aren't free, though. You have to play a little minigame which makes you work for it, which is a nice little twist so you don't reach for the solution immediately. The storyline was engaging and had a satisfying ending. Sneaking around the city was a lot of (often mischievous) fun. The music and excellent art really set the mood, and despite all the grunge, it's quite playful. All in all, Machinarium is wonderful game and absolutely deserves all its awards. I like this game so much, I've even played it twice. Great for all ages.

Posted: April 21, 2014
												Excellent, Beautiful and original adventure set in the old-school point & click style. The comical animations, emotive personalities of the characters through imagery alone, and incredible backdrops all hand-drawn to extremely high quality finish combined with a humorous and engaging storyline clearly outline the level of attention to detail and an affectionate amount of dedication from developers.Machinarium is a great title for those who seek a more cerebral, perhaps slower-paced gameplay than many of the frustrating arcade games around. The puzzles are clearly described and visible clues help to keep on the right track, so there's little chance of being utterly 'stuck'. Even in such situations, there is a buiilt-in diagramatic walkthrough guide for every puzzle that requires a fun little mini-game to view.At such a bargain price, you can't really go wrong with this game. I wholeheartedly recommend Machinarium to any fans of puzzles/adventure games or just gamers in general who seek something a little different...

BUT THIS GAME TOO WAS RESPONSIBLE FOR TURNING MY LIFE AROUND.You play a lovable little robot man desperately trying to make things right in his little mechanical world, while trying to find his little robot girlfriend.It's a charming, delightful game with beautiful  hand-drawn visuals and endearing characters.  It's clever puzzles and breath-taking atmosphere make it a worthwhile addition to any adventure gamer's collection.Seriously.Buy this game.If you have a heart anywhere in your body, you'll love it.

Posted: February 1, 2016
												It's a point-and-click game. The pace is very slow because it is pretty much one long puzzle. Plot, character development, and drama are all minimal.This game tests your ability to patiently observe your surroundings and connect the dots. Everything is laid out clearly but if you aren't paying attention you can spend a lot of time searching for a plunger and feeling dumb once you find it.Casual though it is, I recommend playing with your wits about you and rested rather than just before you go to sleep.Overall the game is not difficult, but there were a few moments when I was utterly stumped and relied on the in-game hint system.If you are looking for something different and somewhat lonely Machinarium fills that niche nicely.

Posted: March 28, 2011
												This is how point and click adventure games should be. The graphics and soundtrack are beautiful; the characters are given depth and emotion without ever speaking a word; the puzzles are clever and varied, and their goals are properly communicated without obvious hints being dropped. Item combinations are intuitive and simple, and generally the only hitch is finding out how to get one of the items required.If at any point a puzzle solution or a goal completely evades you, there are buttons that either give you a hint, or outright tell you the solution (the cost being that you have to play a cute and simple mini game every time you want to check or re-check the solution).Telltale games could learn a lesson or two from this game.

Posted: January 6, 2011
												I've had my eye on this one for a long time, but being a massive tight♥♥♥♥♥♥when it comes to games, I wasn't going to pay $30 for it. Managed to grab it during the Steam Christmas sale, and without a word of a lie, after having played just a couple of hours of it I started to regret not buying the colectors edition (in a pretty tin ie. Halo2) from those stupid♥♥♥♥♥♥♥at EB. The animations are stunning, and the score is perfectly suited to the game, to the point where rather than♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥you off while you're trying to solve puzzles that make you feel like you should be licking the closest window, you actually take the time to listen to them (perfect example is the band puzzle - one of them has a ♥♥♥♥ing didge!) The flash interface is a little rage worthy sometimes, but it's usually just because you're getting angry that you're too much of a spud to solve a puzzle without cheating. Don't play it when you're tired, it takes brain power.

Posted: May 7, 2012
												Years after I played this game, and you know I'm still thinking about it.Machinarium, a point-and-click, third-person adventure game made entirely in flash by a Czech game company.It's a beautiful world full of robots and mechanical equipment. Even the decaying equipment is beautiful to look at. If you like Myst-style adventures, The Neverhood, or games to test your mind instead of your trigger finger, try this one!The puzzles are the ideal balance between inventory, environment, and logic. There is no pixel-hunting here--everything you need is out in the open, you just have to decide how to use it. As you progress, the story gradually becomes clear, and your actions have a purpose. The puzzles are fair and make perfect sense. They never feel like contrived devices to delay the player, but are part of the world. Sometimes they're even fun distractions.As if that weren't enough, the soundtrack is outstanding!The characters are memorable long after finishing the game. The simple story is fun to discover. The puzzles are challenging, but never unfair. It's the perfect balance of humor, challenge, puzzle and action. Check it out!

Posted: June 19, 2016
												Your usual adventure game but with a catch. There's no text in the whole game, relying mostly on visuals to tell its basic story and hint what do do next. The latter is the true challenge of the game, which is not new in this genre, but several puzzles will make you go in circles. Fortunately you have a minigame that if beated, it will give you the full playthrough of the screen you're in, so you can work a little extra to get the solution rather just googling it.The game works in flash and that's probably its main problem. The game runs well, but some inputs can be rough specially as the character has a very limited area to interact with. There's also some puzzles that might feel the game becomes either bugged or unresponsive, so better double check before making assumptions.If you figure out all its puzzles Machinarium is actually pretty short. But due how vague the game is hinting the next step as well the limited interaction range will force you into, is not a game that you can beat by just clicking everything until the character walks into it.

Posted: February 5, 2011
												This is a quaint and short adventure game in which you control a little robot as he tries to uncover an evil scheme. This game takes a little getting used to at first, but once you familiarise yourself with the interface you will not find it too hard to play. One of the nicest features of this particular adventure game is the 'guide book'. If you become stuck, you can play a short minigame to access the guide book which will tell you exactly what to do. That might make it sound a little easy; but the thing is, while the book is open you cannot see the rest of the screen; and whenever you close the book, you must replay the minigame to reopen it. This game is definitely worth checking out, although at $20 it seems a little steep given how short it is.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Excellent game, one of my favorite point-and-clicks! I love the main character, the way the story is presented, and the world it takes place in; also I would have deeply regretted not getting the soundtrack. My only two complaints is that the nuts and bolts tic-tac-toe minigame is always impossible for me to win without a guide, and I find a part of the main story to be a bit cliche (a damsel in distress situation).

Posted: July 2, 2016
												I first played the demo and greatly enjoyed it. The graphics are gorgeous and the characters are incredibly cute. I particularly enjoyed the sounds the characters make and the way they communicate with each other.The mechanics are really neat but I kept forgetting that you can make your robot crouch down or extend its body.The puzzles can be a bit confusing. They're not super hard but it can be tricky to figure out what things are supposed to be and do. I still don't understand the clock tower and I got stuck on the lift for ages. Some puzzles require you to act quickly but they're far from impossible.The robot can give you hints as to what needs to be done and if you need more help you can play a mini game to reveal instructions.The ending was very disappointing to me. It was never really clear what the story was from the beginning or what the little robot was hoping to do but it didn't matter. The atmosphere, graphics and adorable little robots were enough to make it an amazing experience. I especially enjoyed retrieving instruments for a band of musicians and listening to them play.The ending explains what the story was and how your robot ended up on the garbage heap where the game starts and you have to defeat the main bad guys, but it feels very anticlimactic. I think it would feel better if you knew what you were trying to accomplish from the beginning or if it was at least hinted at during the game.The way it plays out you're just controlling a robot who wanders around a city and helps other robots who have been the victims to a pair of robot bullies. Then suddenly an evil master plot is revealed, you defeat the bad guy, and the game has ended.The ending was the only thing in the game I didn't enjoy, though. All in all it's an incredibly charming and very enjoyable game.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												Loved it. I'm that kind of annoying person who only writes bad reviews (albeit constructively). It's not because I give everything bad reviews, but because I only ever feel the drive to write a review when I'm angry that sellers stole my money. I feel like I have to write a good review for Machinarium, though. Knowing that this masterpiece will stay in my Steam account forever, for only £2.09 (70% sale) makes me a happy buyer. It's an artistic game, and what an atmosphere it has, too. Out of all the games I've played in my lifetime, this might be the one most deserving of a 'puzzle game' categorisation. There are puzzles within puzzles. Basically, everything's a puzzle. There's a lot of backtracking to be done to solve certain puzzles, and that's why the game is of a decent length. There aren't many areas in the game, but each area is detailed with care, and most of the areas have to be revisited a number of times. I don't mind this, at all. I've grown to really like the areas in which this game is set, and I got really comfortable and confident with the map. I knew how to get where quite easily, and also, whenever I found or earned a new artefact, I tended to know just where to use it eg. which door it will open, even if that door is relatively far away. The cartooney scrap metal theme, with robots mimicking human life was done brilliantly. It shows that the developers put a lot of time and care into that. Add that to the downtemp/IDM (I think?) soundtrack and you have a brilliant atmosphere. It's also  worth noting that this game is rather funny. The humour was also something that the developers seem to have put a lot of thought into. Although the humour is generally subtle, it will make you laugh out loud if you like the right kind of humour for it, and not too common for it to get old. One flaw I found in this game is that the puzzles are a bit too hard sometimes. As a person who's against ever using guides to beat games, even puzzle games, I'm not ashamed to admit that I did use guides on certain occasions here, and I never regretted it. Rather than thinking "Oh, no! It was that obvious all along!", I was more like, "How was I supposed to know that I should do THAT? I wish I checked a guide an hour ago!". Of course, there are also some puzzles in the game that don't require you to have to figure out what artefact you have to find where to open what, and more obvious puzzles that require skill (and hair-tearing), like doing actual puzzles on game machines to earn coins. These were genuinely really hard and required a lot of time (and similar stuff... people who beat the game will know what I'm talking about). I was not ashamed to use guides to beat these puzzles. I would never in a million years accept to try and do those by myself, they're not worth it. Anyway, I don't want to end this review on a bad note, so I'll just end it by saying that I loved this game. It's different and great. If watching trailers and looking at pictures got you interested in buying this, then buy it! Chances are, it will exceed your expectations like it did mine! :)

Posted: December 19, 2010
												While admittedly short (I played through in roughly 4 hours), this game is solid. The soundtrack is wonderful and the visuals are meticulously detailed and engaging. Machinarium is a throwback to the golden age of point-and-click adventure games (think 90s LucasArts), so if that is something that interests you at all, I recommend this game for you.

Posted: November 25, 2010
												Machinarium is a unique and imaginitive point-and-click adventure that will keep you scratching your head from start to finish, without making you rip your hair out in frustration. The seemingly perfect blend of fine-tuned challenge and whimsical and wholly immersive environments makes this game a tall, refreshing order of distilled enjoyment. However, the relatively short completion time and low replay value make it a game better suited to those with a few extra bucks to burn.

Posted: December 18, 2011
												I love the art in this game. I enjoyed walking through the many screens and seeing all sorts of neat things, especially the robots. The animation is both charming and hilarious. The sound direction is pretty great too, especially the music played after solving a particular series of puzzles.Gameplay-wise, Machinarium is a point-and-click adventure. Most of the puzzles were easy enough to solve without help, though a few left me holding my head for a while. There was only one instance where I could not find the item I needed to progress. Figuring out what to do next was usually no problem due to a helpful "idea bubble" button, and there's also an INCREDIBLY WELL-ILLUSTRATED built-in walkthrough just in case.The plot is minimal, in a good way. The lack of verbal dialogue added to the game's charm. I finished the game in just under 4 hours.Overall, I recommend this game to anyone who wants to play an elegantly simple, stylistically astounding adventure game.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												Machinarium is a fun little game. It's full of puzzles and has a really interesting little world of robots to explore. It can be pretty easy to get lost sometimes though because sometimes your objectives aren't clear. You also have to keep a sharp eye out because some things can be missed pretty easily. There's a good bit of running around back and forth when you're tying to figure things out, but if you get truly stuck the game actually has a walkthrough built inside of it. If you like puzzles and cute robots Machinarium is worth a try. The art is pretty and has a nice sketchy look to it. Plus some of the little robot's reminiscing is   pretty funny. If you liked Botanicula it's made by the same guys so you'll probably like it.

Posted: July 21, 2012
												The game has overall cute if - at some time - repetitive animations (when letting the main charater just sitting there) or having him perform a task. Also remarkable is the hand-drawn scenary at every single screen (there're so much details drawn to match the ambiance).That's combined with increasing difficulty at small technical and logical riddles (say: minigames) all along the way to the goal where it started to go all wrong - that much for revealing the background story.Most of the time you'll have to complete a string of actions before getting to the next screen and more often to solve some brain-teasers to proceed.The real task is mostly to understand what's the goal of the minigame before accomplishing it since there're only abstract hints to the task: one for free by clicking the bulb following an animated film to get  the global picture (rather than having the whole solution picture-wise after sucessfully shooting from a key at lots of moving spiders hanging from a thread).

Posted: April 20, 2012
												If you love puzzle games, or point and click. This is the perfect game for you.This game is a very well put together puzzle game mixed with Point and click.The artstyle is fantastic, the puzzles are equally dificult. Some are easy to figure out, while others leave you scratching your head, wondering what to do. The story in this game is very clear, even though not a single word is spoken throughout the entire game. It's cheap, and may only grant you one or maybe two playthroughs, but i would definitely recommed this game.The music is another thing about the game that is great. You have the option to turn it off, but throughout my nearly 3 hour playthrough of the game, i didn't. I never found it to be annoying or anything like that.The interface is great, very simplistic and minimalistic, but very easy to navigate.It gives you a very easy to follow on how to play the game and use the games different mechanics.I can only recommend this game. Do check it out!

Posted: January 26, 2016
												This is not a game. This is interactive art.Machinarium is among the legendary independent games along with Braid and Limbo.  It was designed by Amanita games, which is known to make similar point&click adventure games.The nameless protagonist of the game is a tin can robot who sets off for journey to find and rescue his girlfriend in a mesmerising machine city, that is Machinarium. You progress through the machine metropolis receiving quests and solving clever puzzles accompanied by stunning visuals and absolutely beautiful soundtrack. You can sense so much love and effort went into both the visual and auditory compenents of the game. I don't know how this game could be made any betterThis is a masterpiece. There are very few games that was able to come this close to perfection.(My one and only slating is about the stubbornness of the developers of not launching their products in Linux including the upcoming Samarost 3 in Q1 2016)

												Nice point-and-click/puzzle game. The art style and created atmosphere are the biggest attractors of this game. Puzzles are clever and on average a bit less random than some other point-and-click games can be, most combinations are logical.HOWEVER, the game is made in Flash and that causes some serious issues you have to deal with. The interface is clunky and saving and loading games can sometimes not work. Posted: April 7, 2015
												This game is short and sweet. It's very pleasant and enjoyable.However, the logic used to solve some of these is absolutely ridiculous. Sometimes, I just sit back and scratch my head trying to figure out what the developers were thinking when they came up with ways to get around some of the problems you face in this game.But once you've solved a puzzle or two, you can figure out where to go in the next few puzzles.Also, it glitched out at the part with the cat that you electrify. For the longest time, my cat didn't work. I thought I was doing the puzzle wrong, so I looked up a walkthrough only to realize I was doing it correctly. When I went back to the spot where I picked up the passed-out cat, another one was lying on the ground there, even though it was already in my inventory. I picked it up again, and it worked to solve the problem after that.8/10, in my opinion.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												We have just completed Machinarium, my 4 year old daughter and me, and if a game can be considered a work of art then this could rightly claim to be one.  Machinarium delivers on all accounts. An engrossing and satisfying puzzle and adventure.  Its scenes richly detailed in equistite detail through its illustrative backgrounds and beautul rendering. Robot characters that have more soul and character than robots have any right to possess. Its games within games that challenge and could be considered orginal in themselves. And a soundtrack that pulls everything together, part ambient electronica, part sound effects, part Radiohead - genius.

Posted: December 23, 2013
												Satisfying when you get it, frusterating when you don't. I love the style of this game by the creators of Botanicula. It's a cute puzzle game. The frustration comes in when you know what needs to be done, but can't do it out of order. Or when you get stuck and walk back and forth doing the same actions over and over expecting a different result. It's kind of like life in that respect. But the satisfaction when you solve a puzzle mostly makes up for it.

Posted: December 22, 2013
												A great, adventure, point-and-click game. If you're looking into this game, get ready for an adventure. You've gotta set yourself in the mindset to be ready to plunge into the world Machinarium presents. It's a really immersive world where you really feel like a part of the story, despite how minimally and beautifully it is told.Technical stuff: The art is great, the puzzles and puzzle difficulty scale really well. It starts off where you can be in a room and complete it with what you can find in your immediate environment, but after a while, you've got to explore a bit. It really gives a sense of progression, and gives you a sense of being a part of a huge world.

												A really good point and click adventure game. BEAUTIFUL graphics. Nice music. Nice storyline. And cheap! And the characters are robots!! WHO DOESN'T LOVE ROBOTS??? This game gets pretty confusing at times, but that's what online walkthroughs are for though ;) Definitely worth your moooolaaaaa!!! :D This game isn't for everyone though. If you don't like the feeling of wanting to rip your hair at times because you're too dumb to figure out what to do next, or the fact there is no dialogue.. then this game is not for you.

Posted: December 18, 2010
												This little flash based game, be it the futuristic music or the beautiful graphics, is a true work of art.  Also there are no long and annoying dialogues which usually can turn an adventure game into a frustrating event;  instead of verbal dialogues all forms of communication are graphical.  Plus, for those who get stuck, the game has a built in illustrated walkthrough for each level, which can be unlocked by playng a short and simple mini-game. The only downside, imo, is that some of the puzzles can be solved only through pure luck and guessing, and not logic, but that is where the built in walkthrough comes to the rescue.  All in all this is a gem of a game that every collector should have in their archive, especially those who want to give their support to independant game makers.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												I first played the demo and greatly enjoyed it. The graphics are gorgeous and the characters are incredibly cute. I particularly enjoyed the sounds the characters make and the way they communicate with each other.The mechanics are really neat but I kept forgetting that you can make your robot crouch down or extend its body.The puzzles can be a bit confusing. They're not super hard but it can be tricky to figure out what things are supposed to be and do. I still don't understand the clock tower and I got stuck on the lift for ages. Some puzzles require you to act quickly but they're far from impossible.The robot can give you hints as to what needs to be done and if you need more help you can play a mini game to reveal instructions.The ending was very disappointing to me. It was never really clear what the story was from the beginning or what the little robot was hoping to do but it didn't matter. The atmosphere, graphics and adorable little robots were enough to make it an amazing experience. I especially enjoyed retrieving instruments for a band of musicians and listening to them play.The ending explains what the story was and how your robot ended up on the garbage heap where the game starts and you have to defeat the main bad guys, but it feels very anticlimactic. I think it would feel better if you knew what you were trying to accomplish from the beginning or if it was at least hinted at during the game.The way it plays out you're just controlling a robot who wanders around a city and helps other robots who have been the victims to a pair of robot bullies. Then suddenly an evil master plot is revealed, you defeat the bad guy, and the game has ended.The ending was the only thing in the game I didn't enjoy, though. All in all it's an incredibly charming and very enjoyable game.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												Loved it. I'm that kind of annoying person who only writes bad reviews (albeit constructively). It's not because I give everything bad reviews, but because I only ever feel the drive to write a review when I'm angry that sellers stole my money. I feel like I have to write a good review for Machinarium, though. Knowing that this masterpiece will stay in my Steam account forever, for only £2.09 (70% sale) makes me a happy buyer. It's an artistic game, and what an atmosphere it has, too. Out of all the games I've played in my lifetime, this might be the one most deserving of a 'puzzle game' categorisation. There are puzzles within puzzles. Basically, everything's a puzzle. There's a lot of backtracking to be done to solve certain puzzles, and that's why the game is of a decent length. There aren't many areas in the game, but each area is detailed with care, and most of the areas have to be revisited a number of times. I don't mind this, at all. I've grown to really like the areas in which this game is set, and I got really comfortable and confident with the map. I knew how to get where quite easily, and also, whenever I found or earned a new artefact, I tended to know just where to use it eg. which door it will open, even if that door is relatively far away. The cartooney scrap metal theme, with robots mimicking human life was done brilliantly. It shows that the developers put a lot of time and care into that. Add that to the downtemp/IDM (I think?) soundtrack and you have a brilliant atmosphere. It's also  worth noting that this game is rather funny. The humour was also something that the developers seem to have put a lot of thought into. Although the humour is generally subtle, it will make you laugh out loud if you like the right kind of humour for it, and not too common for it to get old. One flaw I found in this game is that the puzzles are a bit too hard sometimes. As a person who's against ever using guides to beat games, even puzzle games, I'm not ashamed to admit that I did use guides on certain occasions here, and I never regretted it. Rather than thinking "Oh, no! It was that obvious all along!", I was more like, "How was I supposed to know that I should do THAT? I wish I checked a guide an hour ago!". Of course, there are also some puzzles in the game that don't require you to have to figure out what artefact you have to find where to open what, and more obvious puzzles that require skill (and hair-tearing), like doing actual puzzles on game machines to earn coins. These were genuinely really hard and required a lot of time (and similar stuff... people who beat the game will know what I'm talking about). I was not ashamed to use guides to beat these puzzles. I would never in a million years accept to try and do those by myself, they're not worth it. Anyway, I don't want to end this review on a bad note, so I'll just end it by saying that I loved this game. It's different and great. If watching trailers and looking at pictures got you interested in buying this, then buy it! Chances are, it will exceed your expectations like it did mine! :)

												Really like this one! Beautiful art style, amazing soundtrack and well considered but mostly accessible puzzles. Posted: August 25, 2011
												I couldn't want to anti-recommend a stylish adventure puzzle game more than I anti-recommend Machinarium. The style and atmosphere is brillliant, if I could just get a puzzle game in it that doesn't ruin the whole thing.If you want a hint you get to play a pissant mini-game that is so easy it's just a time sink, one that's especially frustrating if you manage to screw it up because you were so bored with it you weren't paying attention. When you're through with the half-minute of mindless tedium you get a cell by cell comic for a hint, cool, except that IT IS NOT A HINT IT'S A COMPLETE SPOILER FOR THAT WHOLE ROOM! The kicker is, the art work of the spoiler page is so cool, it's almost worth going through the minigame, after you've managed to solve the thing yourself, just to see it. The whole deal spoils the pacing of what was proving to be a charming story.So many interactable items just blend into the background. Out of the first 6 or so rooms. I needed to go through the spoiler process THREE TIMES to find out how the hell I was supposed to do exactly what I already knew I needed to do. Knowing what to do is simple, mindbogglingly easy. Actually clicking the correct thing that blends into the background to be able to do it... 3/5

Posted: May 7, 2012
												Years after I played this game, and you know I'm still thinking about it.Machinarium, a point-and-click, third-person adventure game made entirely in flash by a Czech game company.It's a beautiful world full of robots and mechanical equipment. Even the decaying equipment is beautiful to look at. If you like Myst-style adventures, The Neverhood, or games to test your mind instead of your trigger finger, try this one!The puzzles are the ideal balance between inventory, environment, and logic. There is no pixel-hunting here--everything you need is out in the open, you just have to decide how to use it. As you progress, the story gradually becomes clear, and your actions have a purpose. The puzzles are fair and make perfect sense. They never feel like contrived devices to delay the player, but are part of the world. Sometimes they're even fun distractions.As if that weren't enough, the soundtrack is outstanding!The characters are memorable long after finishing the game. The simple story is fun to discover. The puzzles are challenging, but never unfair. It's the perfect balance of humor, challenge, puzzle and action. Check it out!

Posted: May 5, 2016
 Machinarium So.. Machinarium.. This is really one of those games that allready has so many positive reviews that it might not need another one. But here it goes:Machinarium is set to a universe where there seems to be no humans. Instead there is machines building machines. As you can see from the screenshots posted on the store page of the game, it almost seems like it takes place in a junkyard, where the living machines often are built from scrap metal. Even tho these are machines and don't speak, they have character, and show emotions. Gameplay & Stroy:Machinarium follows the old and well known point and click game mechanic. It is a story driven adventure/puzzle game, that has a rather serious story, but manages to add humor to it on several places.The story captured me from the very first moment that i started playing this. I don't want to ruin the story for those who haven't played this yet, so im not going to cover any part of the story in this review.As mention above, the characters in Machinarium don't speak, but they show thinking boubles above their head and make noises (an alternative way to give the player hints about what they need to do next). This method, in my opinion works very well. Puzzles: I have played many puzzle games and i have to say that for me, this was kind of perfect in terms of difficulty. Many puzzle games tend to become to confusing when they try to make it a big and challenging game. Like having a big area with lots and lots of things to interact with, without a single clue on what to do next. Machinarium manages to give you a lot of different options on what to interact with, but at the same time you get enough hints on what your goal is that you for example knows that you have to do someting with this item, just not what. Level design:The levels in Machinarium are great actually. There is a lot of variations and different enviroments through out the game. They also made the levels in a way that you get a feeling of a big living world even outside of the playable areas. You still have to remember that this is a sideview game with limited possibilities of movement. Still, there is depth in the levels, so you can for example walk away and towards the camera. Nostalgia:For me these kinds of games gives me some nostalgia from the time around 2001-2006 when i used to play games like these on flash sites all the time. There is something "calming" about sitting there without any stress, and figuring out these sorts of games. Of course Machinarium is more polished, longer and better than most free flash games out there.Bugs & Crashes:So far in my review, i've only said positive things about Machinarium. But as many other games before it, Machinarium suffers when it comes to bugs and crashes. I experienced several times during my playthrough that the games just froze with a black screen. I still could hear the music but i had to close it through task manager and restart it to keep playing. I also experienced that the game just closed for no apparent reason, and sometimes while playing and i clicked on something, nothing happened in-game. But since this is a very small game in terms of size, and that it practically doesn't require anything to run, it took me seconds to restart and be back in it. Conclusion:Machinarium is a great game, really. If you like story driven puzzle games i would recommend you to get this.

												Great, short adventure game.Pros:   • Art style (simple, pleasant and cute)   • Music (simple and yet you won't tire of it quickly)   • Puzzles (simple in design and yet challenging and rewarding)Cons:   • Sometimes you have to do things, because you can interact with an object - not because you know what you are doing. Posted: April 8
												I love this game. I bought it years ago because the artwork intrigued me. I played it for a little while, but set it aside, but it had always stuck with me. Today, I started it up again, and I didn't stop until I was finished with it. I love point and click adventure games, but I'm not great at solving puzzles, really. For me, feeling in a casual mood, the puzzles were just challening enough, and the little hint dynamic definitely came in handy. Mostly, though, the game and its atmosphere is just wonderful. The artwork is amazingly detailed, and the style makes rust and decay seem charming. I don't think there is a forgettable character in the entire cast, and they are animated wonderfully. The music is great. It complements the game incredibly well, and it's nice to listen to even as an album. The replacement of dialog with animated pictorial thought bubbles is a novel choice, and makes for a fun narrative that doesn't require any reading.I really can't think of any drawbacks to Machinarium. It was just what I wanted to fill a leisurely afternoon with an amusing and heartfelt single-sitting game.

Posted: January 26
												This game is straight up HARD, with the average time on each screen totalling in to a whopping 4 and a half minutes.  It's rich art style and marked isolationism makes it a charming adventure to top of this indie bundle.  The player will most-definitely, at all times, feel completely alone throughout the adventure.  Luckily, the threats aren't directed at the player at all, and it illustrates nothing more than a lost soul wandering through a seemingly-moving, but stagnant world.It's a 3.5/5.

Posted: September 28, 2012
												I can only suggest this game if you have the patience for point and click adventures. I can say I got about 90% done before I got to a point where I felt like I NEEDED a FAQ to get past - I would have to remember a very hard to remember tone to make a ladder appear, that disappears within seconds, plus a hard ...Node dragging? puzzle and having to find some way to get the girl back with a fan. Some of that I could probably take care of, but I got irritated once I met the tone puzzle. I love the look of Amanita games, but hate how thier design affects gameplay, making solutions seems very obscure.

												A gorgeous game with a great soundtrack. It's really soothing to walk around the quietly decaying robot city. The other robots were interesting, and I loved the greenhouse and the robot band.The puzzles and minigames have great variety, and I really enjoyed them, even if I did need the walkthrough occasionally.

Posted: January 18
												This is a really enjoyable point-and-click game - in fact, I have played it many times already (after giving myself enough time to forget the solutions for the puzzles).PROS- The story is fun and cute (specially if you allow the robot to idle for some time, as it starts to have some animated flashbacks)- Beautiful 2D artwork, actually animated (nowadays many point-and-click games look like jointed paper dolls)- Challenging and diversified puzzle styles (and some nice minigames included!)- No pixel hunting- Well polishedCONS- Some puzzles won't allow resetting- Some puzzles/minigames won't allow different input methods (there is one where using a keyboard instead of the mouse would be greatly helpful)- No achievements (well, the game is pretty straightforward and by the end everyone would have 100%, but it'd be nice to have something to indicate the ending was achieved)

Posted: July 23, 2015
Machinarium is a very artistic and difficult point and click game about robots. There are plenty of funny moments with the way your character interacts with the environment and the antagonists are explained through visual representations. There is one hint per area that was helpful. There is also a book that will show everything that needs to be done in that area after you finish a minigame to earn that information. I am recommending this game for people who have patience for it's difficulty, enjoy great artwork, and like a steampunk/robotic themed world..

Posted: July 4, 2016
Do robots dream of electric sheep?City robots Mashinarium, smelling of oil and covered with rust, live the life of a giant mechanism. You would never think that the same vending machine for batteries is also a robot! Originally posted by Jakub Dvorsky: - It happened on a distant and forgotten planet, where people used to send the garbage that they were producing old machines, mechanisms, computers, etc. This mechanical scrap was formed a few simple robots. Some time later they built other, more advanced robots, and then — settlement. Thus was created the city of Machinarium.  You play as a robot named Josef, Yes, our hero has a name, though it is not mentioned. You mistakenly throw away to the city dump, your girlfriend is kidnapped by the bandit and all around town is in danger! And who do you need to solve these problems? Of course You. Maybe You look funny, but full of resoluteness and courage.And so begins your exciting journey in the city of rusted steel, constantly working mechanisms and sleepless, the most diverse and unusual residents.Machinarium - a game of Czech developer Amanita Design company. Was created by the efforts of only 7 people and was sponsored by savings of developers. Guys, only 7 developers! And the project turned out just beautiful! Won many awards and entered the top 10 of "Best games of 2009" and is a game created in Adobe flash. Unlike stamped new games, before, tried to make something different, unique and memorable. In the game everything is fine. Great atmosphere, which is felt not only in the image created manually, but in a beautiful soundtrack. Each composition, each location gives a feeling of positivity and a sense of independent life of the city. Unusual for the time mechanics, which is expressed in the interaction of objects in the vicinity of the character, the change in the growth of Joseph and a complete lack of dialogue. The soundtrack deserves special mention. To listen to it forever. It is so beautiful that takes your mind straight to Machinarium, and your imagination just explodes. It also blends perfectly with real life. Listen to the song "The Bottom" or "Mr. Handagote" and watch the bustling city, just great.Puzzles also did not disappoint. They are funny, interesting and sometimes challenging. Will have to break your head a little bit, but it's worth it. Of course, the developers have simplified the game and after the passage of a small scrolling shooter, you can spy hints at this level. But I assure you, to do everything yourself - a lot of fun. Go back to the game and to pass it on a new, never get bored. She always looks fresh and breathtaking. I replayed it for the umpteenth time since its release and purchase the disc, and it is October 2009. 7 years, the game is not removed from my computer.Well, go ahead! Who knows what the outcome of Your little adventure?The game is definitely worth the money. And I hope, one day, will be its continuation.OVER9000 small Josefov out of 10.
